description: Abies concolor has a distinctive tall, pyramid-like form and features eye-catching blue-grey needles. It flourishes in areas that experience long winters and mild summers, and it can endure dry soil conditions and even short periods of drought once it's well-established. Nevertheless, it prefers to grow in soil that is moist and well-draining, and it struggles in heavy clay or persistently wet soils. Abies concolor is an ideal choice for container gardening or as a bonsai subject, and it's also a great option as a Christmas tree. Abies concolor is evergreen and native to the United States and Mexico. Learn more about Abies concolor.

Acacia baileyana 'Purpurea' has greyish-green fern-like leaves, and when new growth appears, it's a beautiful shade of purple. During the winter, this tree is covered in a profusion of golden-yellow flowers. It thrives in soil that is dry and stony, and it needs to have proper drainage. Once this tree has taken root, it can endure periods of drought. All in all, it's a remarkable tree that has both stunning foliage and blossoms. Acacia baileyana is evergreen and native to the state of New South Wales in Australia. Learn more about Acacia baileyana.

Acacia floribunda has an elegant, wide-spreading, and bushy shape with an open form and slender leaves. In late winter and spring, this tree produces delightful, pale-yellow flowers that form fluffy clusters and exude a pleasant fragrance. Acacia floribunda can tolerate heavy clay soils as well as periodically wet soils. Although it can endure dry soil in a garden setting, it prefers to grow in soil that is consistently moist or wet. Acacia floribunda is a versatile choice that can be employed as a windbreak, hedge, or screen. Acacia floribunda is evergreen and native to Australia. Learn more about Acacia floribunda.

Acacia howittii is available for sale in New Zealand in a dwarf, weeping variety. It's a charming tree that grows gracefully, with branches that hang down. It prefers to grow in soil that is moist and well-drained, but it can withstand short periods of drought. Acacia howittii produces fragrant, pale-yellow flowers during the spring season. It's also a great option for bonsai enthusiasts. Acacia howittii is evergreen and native to the state of Victoria in Australia. Learn more about Acacia howittii.

Acacia melanoxylon is highly valued for its exquisite marbled wood. It's a fast-growing and robust tree that provides ample shade and shelter. Acacia melanoxylon has a dense, rounded crown, and it produces lovely, pale-yellow flowers during late winter and early spring. It can thrive in regions with high rainfall and can tolerate some drought, but it prefers to grow in soil that is consistently moist. Its shallow root system features densely packed, surface-level roots that feed heavily from the soil. Additionally, this tree is capable of converting atmospheric nitrogen into the soil, which benefits the surrounding environment. It's an excellent choice for hedges, screens, and shelterbelts. Acacia melanoxylon is evergreen and native to Australia. Learn more about Acacia melanoxylon.

This hardy maple is an excellent choice for street plantings and as a shade tree. It initially grows in an upright pattern, which gradually transforms into a rounded canopy as it matures. Acer buergerianum's new growth appears as a striking copper-red hue, which later turns green during summer. During autumn, the leaves turn into vivid shades of red, apricot, and yellow. Acer buergerianum thrives in full sun and requires well-drained soil. Once it's established, it can endure windy conditions and is somewhat tolerant of drought. Acer buergerianum also has a moderate ability to tolerate coastal environments and can handle air pollution. It's a great option for bonsai enthusiasts. Acer buergerianum is deciduous and native to China, Taiwan, and Japan. Learn more about Acer buergerianum.

Acer campbellii 'Gwavas' has sizable leaves that are deeply-lobed and begin as bronze-purple before transitioning to an olive-green color with prominent veins. It has an upright, spreading growth pattern. During the autumn season, the leaves take on vibrant hues of yellow and orange, which make them appear to glow. Acer campbellii 'Gwavas' thrives in full sun and prefers moist, well-drained soil. Acer campbellii is deciduous and native to China, Bhutan, northern India, Myanmar, Nepal, and Vietnam. Learn more about Acer campbellii. Acer campbellii 'Gwavas' was discovered at Gwavas Station in Tikokino, Hawkes Bay, New Zealand.

otherCommonNames: Hedge Maple, Feldahorn, Veldesdoorn, Spaanse Aak
description: Acer campestre has a compact structure and features a dense, rounded canopy, along with corky bark. It has small leaves that are rounded with lobes and appear dark green in the summer months, transitioning into a beautiful yellow color during the fall season. Acer campestre prefers soil that is moist and well-drained but can still withstand dry and clay soils. It's also able to tolerate air pollution, making it a great choice for urban environments. Acer campestre produces green, inconspicuous flowers in early to mid-spring. Additionally, it can handle strong winds and coastal sites. Bonsai enthusiasts would enjoy growing this tree. Acer campestre is deciduous and native to much of Europe, southwest Asia from Turkey to the Caucasus Mountains, and the Atlas mountains in north Africa. Learn more about Acer campestre.

otherCommonNames: Hair-foot Maple, Red Snakebark Maple, Kyushu Maple, Hosoe-Kaede, Ashiboso-urinoki
description: Acer capillipes has a vase-like shape, with red new stems and bark that features green and white stripes. During autumn, the leaves take on orange and scarlet tones, which provide a stunning display. Acer capillipes prefers soil that is moist and well-drained, as well as part-shade, particularly in hot climates. It can also tolerate air pollution, making it a suitable option for urban environments. Acer capillipes is deciduous and native to the islands of Honshū, Kyūshū, and Shikoku in Japan. Learn more about Acer capillipes.

otherCommonNames: Caucasian Maple, Coliseum Maple, Colchican Maple
description: During spring, this tree produces young foliage that is bright-yellow with orange-red margins. As summer approaches, the leaves transition to a light-green color. However, during autumn, the leaves turn bright-yellow, creating a lovely display. Acer cappadocicum 'Aureum' can tolerate periods of drought but prefers soil that is moist and well-drained. It's worth noting that this tree has a shallow root system. It's best to avoid exposed, windy areas when planting this tree. Acer cappadocicum is deciduous and native to Asia, from central Turkey (ancient Cappadocia) east along the Caucasus and the Himalayas to southwestern China. Learn more about Acer cappadocicum. Acer cappadocicum 'Aureum' was first introduced by Hesse Nurseries of Weener, Germany in 1914.

otherCommonNames: Caucasian Maple, Coliseum Maple, Colchican Maple
description: During spring, this tree produces new leaves that are a striking blood-red color. Throughout summer, the leaves remain large and green. Acer cappadocicum 'Rubrum' has a compact, rounded crown and can tolerate periods of drought, but prefers soil that is moist and well-drained. Acer cappadocicum 'Rubrum' has a shallow root system. It's best to avoid exposed, windy areas when planting this tree. Acer cappadocicum is deciduous and native to Asia, from central Turkey (ancient Cappadocia) east along the Caucasus and the Himalayas to southwestern China. Learn more about Acer cappadocicum. Acer caudatifolium 'Summer Surprise' boasts stunning features throughout the year. Acer caudatifolium 'Summer Surprise' grows best in part-shade and prefers soil that is moist and well-drained. It's important to keep this tree sheltered from strong winds. One of this tree's standout features is its striped bark. Acer caudatifolium is deciduous and native to Taiwan. Learn more about Acer caudatifolium.

Acer davidii has an erect, open, and spreading form, and its bark is shiny and green with silver-white stripes. Acer davidii prefers soil that is moist and well-drained and is best suited for growing in part-shade. Acer davidii is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Acer davidii.

Acer japonicum 'Vitifolium' has a stiff, spreading branch structure and its leaves are similar to grapevine foliage. Acer japonicum 'Vitifolium' prefers moist, well-drained soils in part-shade, and can grow in full sun but may experience leaf scorch in hot summers. Acer monspessulanum has a rounded, densely-branched form and features thick, leathery leaves. Its autumn leaves are yellow in color. This is an upright tree with striking carmine-pink and green leaves in spring, transitioning to white and green in summer, and ultimately to red in autumn. It is a great fit for smaller gardens and produces small, yellow-green flowers in early to mid-spring. However, it does not tolerate shade or strong winds, and its seeds are toxic to horses. Furthermore, this tree is highly tolerant of cold temperatures and windy conditions. Acer rubrum is deciduous and native to eastern North America. Learn more about Acer rubrum. Acer rubrum 'Scanlon' was selected in 1956 by Scanlon Nursery of Olmsted Falls, Ohio, United States.

Acer saccharinum features light-green leaves with lobes and silver undersides that create a beautiful visual effect when rustled by the wind. During the autumn season, its leaves turn yellow. With an open vase shape, it grows rapidly, but its shallow root system can cause issues by uplifting sidewalks and driveways, and damaging pipes. It is ideal for areas with wet soil or seasonal flooding. Although it can tolerate some wind, it may sustain damage during strong winds. While it can develop weak limbs as it ages, it remains an excellent option for quickly providing shade in challenging soil conditions. Acer saccharinum is deciduous and native to eastern and central United States and southeastern Canada. Learn more about Acer saccharinum.

Acer saccharum boasts large, green, lobed leaves that transform into stunning autumnal hues of red, orange, and yellow in colder regions. It has a compact crown and up-swept branches, and its sap is commercially used for producing maple syrup. However, this tree is sensitive to heat and air pollution, and its roots have the potential to damage pipes and crack sidewalks. It requires moist, well-drained soil and is not suited for dry or poorly draining soil types. Additionally, it is not tolerant of moderate to strong winds. Acer saccharum is one of the major sources of sap for making maple syrup and is deciduous and native to the hardwood forests of eastern Canada and eastern United States. Learn more about Acer saccharum.

Acer shirasawanum 'Autumn Moon' has apricot-orange leaves during the spring that transition to a yellow-green hue in the summer. During the autumn season, the leaves turn orange and yellow. It is important to protect this tree from direct sunlight, as the leaves can easily get scorched. It is also recommended to provide shelter from strong winds. To support healthy growth, this tree should be grown in moist and well-drained soil. Acer shirasawanum is deciduous and native to Honshū, Shikoku, and Kyūshū islands in Japan. Learn more about Acer shirasawanum. Acer shirasawanum 'Autumn Moon' was discovered as a seedling by J. D. Vertrees at Maplewood Nursery in Roseburg, Oregon, United States.

Acer tschonoskii showcases green leaves during the spring and summer months, while displaying autumnal shades of yellow, red, and orange as the seasons change. When young, it grows in a compact, upright manner, but as it ages, it has a tendency to spread out. Acer tschonoskii is deciduous and native to Japan and the Kuril Islands. Learn more about Acer tschonoskii.

Aesculus x carnea has a wide, round head and large, fan-shaped dark-green leaves. It produces giant red flower candles in late-spring, and glossy-brown nuts in the autumn, which are toxic to both humans and animals. The foliage may scorch in very dry or windy conditions. Aesculus x carnea is challenging to transplant once established due to its taproot. It is ideal for use as a shade, avenue, or paddock tree, and it displays beautiful golden-yellow leaves during the autumn season. Aesculus x carnea prefers moist and well-drained soil and does not tolerate dry soil well. Aesculus x carnea is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Aesculus pavia and Aesculus hippocastanum. Learn more about Aesculus x carnea.

Aesculus x carnea 'Briotii' is a compact grower and has large, dark-green, fan-shaped leaves. It produces giant red flower candles in late spring, and its glossy-brown nuts in autumn are toxic to humans and animals. The foliage is susceptible to scorching in dry or windy conditions. Once established, this tree is challenging to transplant due to its taproot. It is an excellent choice for use as a shade, avenue, or paddock tree, and it showcases beautiful golden-yellow leaves during the autumn season. Aesculus x carnea 'Briotii' has larger flowers than Aesculus x carnea and is slower-growing due to the greater number of flowers it produces, and will ultimately mature as a smaller tree. It prefers moist, well-drained soils and does not tolerate dry soils well. Aesculus x carnea is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Aesculus pavia and Aesculus hippocastanum. Learn more about Aesculus x carnea. Aesculus x carnea 'Briotii' was raised from seed in Trianon-Versailles near Paris, France in 1858. Named in 1858 to honor Pierre Louis Briot (1804-1888), the chief horticulturist of the State gardens at Trianon-Versailles.

Aesculus hippocastanum is tall and stately, with a wide crown. It boasts large, deep-green, fan-shaped leaves and produces giant white flower candles in mid-spring. In the autumn, it bears glossy-brown nuts that are toxic to humans and animals. The foliage is susceptible to scorching in dry or windy conditions. Once established, it is difficult to transplant due to its taproot. Aesculus hippocastanum is well-suited for use in large gardens, parks, and paddocks, and it displays beautiful yellow leaves during the autumn season. It prefers moist, well-drained soil and does not tolerate dry soil well. Aesculus hippocastanum is deciduous and native to a small area in the Pindus Mountains (Northern Greece) mixed forests and Balkan (Albania) mixed forests of southeast Europe. Learn more about Aesculus hippocastanum.

Aesculus hippocastanum 'Baumannii' is characterized by large, dark-green, fan-shaped leaves and produces giant double white flower candles in mid-spring. It has a narrower growth habit and blooms later and for a longer duration compared to Aesculus hippocastanum. The flowers of this tree are mostly sterile, resulting in minimal fruit production. The nuts produced in autumn are toxic to humans and animals. Once established, this tree is challenging to transplant due to its taproot. It is ideal for use as a shade or paddock tree and features yellow autumn leaves. Aesculus hippocastanum 'Baumannii' prefers moist, well-drained soil and does not tolerate dry soil well. Aesculus hippocastanum is deciduous and native to a small area in the Pindus Mountains (Northern Greece) mixed forests and Balkan (Albania) mixed forests of southeast Europe. Learn more about Aesculus hippocastanum. Aesculus hippocastanum 'Baumannii' was noticed by A. N. Baumann (according to him) as a sport on a tree of Aesculus hippocastanum growing in the garden of a Mons. Duval, near Geneva, during the years 1819 to 1822. He sent grafts to his father's famous nursery at Bollwiller in Alsace, France, from whence it spread into cultivation.

Aesculus indica has large and attractive leaves that initially appear as bronze-green in spring and then mature to a dark-green hue by summer. It produces frilly, white flower panicles in early to mid-summer, about a month later than Aesculus hippocastanum. The white flowers have a red flush and yellow spots. In autumn, this tree bears glossy-brown nuts that are toxic to humans and animals. It is an excellent shade tree, and its leaves turn beautiful shades of orange and yellow during the autumn season. Aesculus indica thrives in moist, well-drained soil and does not tolerate dry soil well. Aesculus indica is deciduous and native to the Himalayan Lowlands, between Kashmir and Western Nepal at elevations between 900 and 3,000 metres. Learn more about Aesculus indica.

Aesculus x neglecta 'Erythroblastos' showcases remarkable new leaves that are pink-orange in color and gradually change to cream-green as spring progresses and become green throughout the summer season. It has a slow growth rate, and it is essential to protect it from strong winds. During spring, this tree produces pale-yellow flowers with a red base, borne in erect panicles. As the autumn season arrives, its leaves turn beautiful shades of orange and yellow. Aesculus x neglecta 'Erythroblastos' seldom produces nuts. Aesculus x neglecta is deciduous and possibly a hybrid between Aesculus flava (syn. Aesculus octandra) and Aesculus sylvatica. Learn more about Aesculus x neglecta. Aesculus x neglecta 'Erythroblastos' was first distributed by Späth nursery in Berlin, Germany before 1935.

Aesculus turbinata has huge, fan-shaped leaves and produces large, red-spotted, white flower panicles in late-spring. It bears glossy-brown nuts in the autumn that are toxic to humans and animals. Aesculus turbinata is excellent for use as a large shade tree, and it displays beautiful yellow leaves during the autumn season. Aesculus turbinata is deciduous and native to Japan. Learn more about Aesculus turbinata.

Afrocarpus mannii grows densely and can be trimmed to form a hedge. Its long leaves are fresh-green when young. It is a quick and vigorous grower. Afrocarpus mannii is evergreen and native to the Afromontane forests of São Tomé Island in the Gulf of Guinea, growing at altitudes of 1,300m up to the summit at 2,024m. Learn more about Afrocarpus mannii.

This slender, pyramidal tree has the ability to fit into a confined space for several years, despite kauri trees attaining a broad size with age. When young, it needs protection from frosts and wind, and requires moist soil during dry periods for establishing. However, it can tolerate light frosts and heavy clay soils once it has matured. The leaves of this tree are bronze when young, maturing to green with age. Agathis australis thrives in moist, well-drained soil. Agathis australis is evergreen and native to the northern regions of New Zealand's North Island. Learn more about Agathis australis.

This erect, pyramidal tree features young leaves that are bronze in color and is characterized by larger leaves compared to our native kauri, Agathis australis. When young, it requires protection from frosts and wind, as well as moist soil during dry periods for establishing. Once established, it can tolerate light frosts and heavy clay soils. Agathis robusta thrives in moist, well-drained soil. Agathis robusta is evergreen and native to Papua New Guinea and the state of Queensland in Australia. Learn more about Agathis robusta.

Agonis flexuosa is characterized by a pendulous habit and produces small, white flowers in the spring and summer months. It has long, slender, dark-green leaves and is drought tolerant once established. It can tolerate moderate coastal winds and is best suited for moist, sandy soils, but can adapt to other well-drained soils. Agonis flexuosa is an excellent option for use as a street tree as it responds well to trimming under power lines, and it can also be utilized for screening off areas to provide privacy. Agonis flexuosa is evergreen and native to the southwest of Western Australia in a subcoastal strip from just north of Perth, southward through the Swan Coastal Plain, then along the coast to outlying islands east of Bremer Bay. Learn more about Agonis flexuosa.

Albizia julibrissin produces deep-pink, silky, fragrant summer flowers with ferny leaves on its wide-spreading branches. It does not leaf out until very late in the spring, and it is an excellent choice for use as a shade tree. Albizia julibrissin is capable of tolerating heat and drought, and it flowers best when it is grown in full-sun. However, it has weak limbs that are susceptible to damage from strong winds, snow, and ice. Its seeds and seedpods are severely toxic to both humans and animals. Albizia julibrissin is easy to transplant. Albizia julibrissin is deciduous and native to southwestern and eastern Asia. Learn more about Albizia julibrissin.

Albizia julibrissin 'Red Silk' is characterized by deep-pink, silky, fragrant summer flowers that appear on its wide-spreading branches, which are adorned with ferny leaves. It does not leaf out until very late in the spring and is an excellent shade tree. Albizia julibrissin 'Red Silk' is capable of tolerating both heat and drought, and it tends to flower best when it is grown in full-sun. However, it has weak limbs that can be damaged by strong winds, snow, and ice. Its seeds and seedpods are severely toxic to both humans and animals. Albizia julibrissin 'Red Silk' is easy to transplant. Albizia julibrissin is deciduous and native to southwestern and eastern Asia. Learn more about Albizia julibrissin. Albizia julibrissin 'Red Silk' was selected and introduced by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand.

Albizia julibrissin 'Rosea' is distinguished by its silky, pink, and fragrant summer flowers that appear on its wide-spreading branches, which are adorned with ferny leaves. It does not leaf out until very late in the spring, and it makes for an excellent shade tree that can tolerate heat and drought. It typically flowers best when grown in full-sun. However, it has weak limbs that can be damaged by strong winds, snow, and ice. Its seeds and seedpods are severely toxic to both humans and animals. Albizia julibrissin 'Rosea' is easy to transplant. Albizia julibrissin is deciduous and native to southwestern and eastern Asia. Learn more about Albizia julibrissin.

Albizia julibrissin 'Summer Chocolate' features rich chocolate-burgundy, ferny leaves on its wide-spreading branches, which are adorned with silky, pink, and fragrant flowers in the summer. It typically does not leaf out until very late in the spring and is an excellent option for use as a shade tree. It flowers best when grown in full-sun and can tolerate heat and drought. However, it has weak limbs that can be damaged by strong winds, snow, and ice. Its seeds and seedpods are severely toxic to both humans and animals. Albizia julibrissin 'Summer Chocolate' is easy to transplant. Albizia julibrissin is deciduous and native to southwestern and eastern Asia. Learn more about Albizia julibrissin. Albizia julibrissin 'Summer Chocolate' was discovered in a controlled breeding program in Japan and selected by Masato Yokoi from thousands of seedlings in 1990. After testing and trial growing in selected gardens it was introduced into the United States and patented in 2003.

Alectryon excelsus grows upright with a rounded head and produces a mix of orange and rose-pink new leaves that mature into glossy, olive-green, pinnate leaves. During the summer, it bears shiny black seeds that emerge from scarlet arils (an outgrowth that covers the seed), which are attractive to seed-eating birds. It can tolerate light frosts once established and makes for an excellent shade tree and street tree. Alectryon excelsus thrives in moist, well-drained soil. Alectryon excelsus is evergreen and native to New Zealand, in coastal and lowland forests throughout most of the North Island and from Banks Peninsula to central Westland in the South Island. Learn more about Alectryon excelsus.
uses: street, attracts-birds, paddocks, shade, topiary, pleaching

description: Alnus cordata is characterized by its shining, heart-shaped, green leaves and quick-growing, upright form. It can grow in both moist, swampy soils and dry, infertile soils, making it useful for erosion control and windbreaks. It is an excellent option for use as a street or shade tree. During the early to mid-spring months, it produces yellow-green catkins that serve as a source of pollen for bees. Furthermore, this tree can fix nitrogen in the soil, which is beneficial for improving soil conditions for other plants. Alnus cordata is deciduous and native to the southern Apennine Mountains in Italy (Campania, Basilicata and Calabria, mainly on western mountain sides) and the north-eastern mountains of Corsica. Learn more about Alnus cordata.

Alnus glutinosa is characterized by its pyramidal form and ability to thrive in very wet areas. It can also tolerate dry, infertile soils and is a vigorous, quick-growing plant. It is an excellent option for use as a shelter tree and is great for erosion control and stabilizing river banks. During the early to mid-spring months, it produces yellow-green catkins that serve as a source of pollen for bees. Furthermore, this tree can fix nitrogen in the soil, which is beneficial for improving soil conditions for other plants. Alnus glutinosa is deciduous and native to almost the whole of continental Europe (except for both the extreme north and south) as well as the United Kingdom and Ireland. Learn more about Alnus glutinosa.

Alnus glutinosa 'Imperialis' is characterized by its elegant appearance and outspreading branches. It features fine and deeply-cut, green leaves and is tolerant of wet soils, making it an excellent choice for planting near water. During the early to mid-spring months, it produces yellow-green catkins that serve as a source of pollen for bees. Furthermore, this tree can fix nitrogen in the soil, which is beneficial for improving soil conditions for other plants. Alnus glutinosa is deciduous and native to almost the whole of continental Europe (except for both the extreme north and south) as well as the United Kingdom and Ireland. Learn more about Alnus glutinosa. Alnus glutinosa 'Imperialis' has an unknown origin, but has been in cultivation since before 1859.

Alnus glutinosa 'Laciniata' features a conical-growing shape and finely-cut, green leaves. It is capable of tolerating wet and windy sites, making it a resilient choice for outdoor planting. During the early to mid-spring months, it produces yellow-green catkins that serve as a source of pollen for bees. Furthermore, this tree can fix nitrogen in the soil, which is beneficial for improving soil conditions for other plants. Alnus glutinosa is deciduous and native to almost the whole of continental Europe (except for both the extreme north and south) as well as the United Kingdom and Ireland. Learn more about Alnus glutinosa. Alnus glutinosa 'Laciniata' originated in France in the early 1800s. It is said that Trochereau de la Berliere found this form growing in the wild, which he took and planted in his garden near Saint Germain.

Alnus incana 'Aurea' is a large, conical-shaped plant that produces yellow leaves in the spring, which mature to yellow-green in the summer before turning yellow in the autumn. The young branches are orange-yellow, providing a stunning display in the winter months. During the early to mid-spring, it produces red-pink catkins that serve as a source of pollen for bees. Furthermore, this tree can fix nitrogen in the soil, which is beneficial for improving soil conditions for other plants. Alnus incana is deciduous and native to various regions across the Northern Hemisphere. Learn more about Alnus incana. Alnus incana 'Aurea' was raised in Germany in the late-1800s, and potentially released into commerce in 1892.

Alnus inokumae is a fast and straight-growing alder that features attractive, dark-green leaves. It is an excellent option for use as a fast-growing screening tree and is capable of tolerating wet sites. During the early to mid-spring months, it produces yellow-green catkins that serve as a source of pollen for bees. Additionally, this tree can fix nitrogen in the soil, which is beneficial for improving soil conditions for other plants. In the autumn months, its leaves turn yellow, adding a lovely touch of color to any outdoor space. Alnus inokumae is deciduous and native to the islands of Honshu and Hokkaido in Japan. Learn more about Alnus inokumae.

Alnus jorullensis is fast-growing and features long, green, toothed leaves. It is easy to prune and can be shaped to suit a variety of needs. It is an excellent option for use as a dense screen or privacy hedge. During the early to mid-spring months, it produces yellow-green catkins that serve as a source of pollen for bees. Additionally, this tree can fix nitrogen in the soil, which is beneficial for improving soil conditions for other plants. Alnus jorullensis is evergreen and native to eastern and southern Mexico, Guatemala, and Honduras. Learn more about Alnus jorullensis.

Alnus rubra features a slender, pyramidal form and produces red buds that reveal red-green catkins in the spring. Its green leaves have a blue-green underside and the inner bark is orange-red, adding a lovely touch of color to any outdoor space. It is a hardy plant that is capable of tolerating moist soils. During the early to mid-spring months, it produces catkins that serve as a source of pollen for bees. Additionally, this tree can fix nitrogen in the soil, which is beneficial for improving soil conditions for other plants. Alnus rubra is deciduous and native to western North America. Learn more about Alnus rubra.

Amelanchier canadensis is a compact and tidy tree with a rounded head. Its bronze new leaves in the spring turn into a stunning array of red, yellow, and orange in the autumn, adding a lovely touch of color to any outdoor space. In the late winter to late spring months, it produces lacy, white, drooping flower clusters. During the early summer, it also produces edible berries that start out red and then turn purple when they are ripe and ready to eat. Amelanchier canadensis is deciduous and native to eastern North America in Canada from Newfoundland west to southern Ontario, and in the United States from Maine south to Alabama. Learn more about Amelanchier canadensis.

Araucaria araucana is slow-growing and features a pyramidal growth habit when young that spreads out with age. It has leathery, spiky, triangle-shaped leaves on widely-spaced branches, adding a unique and interesting texture to any outdoor space. Araucaria araucana is evergreen and native to central and southern Chile and western Argentina. Learn more about Araucaria araucana.

Araucaria heterophylla is a stately and erect tree with a pyramidal form, making it an ideal hardy coastal tree. It is an enduring tree that works well in large outdoor spaces. Additionally, it can be grown in a container and kept small, making it a versatile option for a variety of outdoor spaces. Araucaria heterophylla is evergreen and native to Norfolk Island. Learn more about Araucaria heterophylla.

otherCommonNames: Canary Madrone, Canary Islands Strawberry Tree
description: Arbutus canariensis has bold and attractive green foliage. In autumn to early winter, large, upright panicles of white-pink, bell-shaped flowers cover this tree, making it a great source of pollen for bees. It also produces green fruit in the winter after the flowers, which take almost a full year to ripen. The fruit changes color from yellow to red and ripens when the next year's autumn flowers appear. The fruit is a favorite of birds. Arbutus canariensis has peeling, red-brown bark and is tolerant of wind and heat, making it a great option for a variety of outdoor spaces. Arbutus canariensis is evergreen and native to the Canary Islands of Spain. Learn more about Arbutus canariensis.

otherCommonNames: Irish Strawberry Tree, Killarney Strawberry Tree, Cane Apple
description: Arbutus unedo is very hardy and can withstand adverse conditions such as coastal, heat, and cold environments. It produces small, white flowers in autumn and winter, which are a great source of pollen for bees. It also produces green fruit in the winter after the flowers, which take almost a full year to ripen. The fruit changes color from yellow to red and ripens when the next year's autumn flowers appear. Birds love the fruit, making it a great addition to a garden or outdoor space. Arbutus unedo has peeling, red-brown bark, which adds to its attractive appearance. Arbutus unedo is evergreen and native to the Mediterranean region and western Europe. Learn more about Arbutus unedo.

In spring, it produces cream to rose-pink flowers, which are followed by dark-red to purple-black berries in summer that are attractive to native birds. The leaves may have pink-red undersides. It can tolerate light frosts and may be semi-evergreen in colder climates. Aristotelia serrata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Aristotelia serrata.

A decorative plant that grows in clusters and has broad, spiky, silver-green leaves that hang down at the ends. It can be grown easily in areas with full sun or partial shade, and it can tolerate both damp and dry conditions. It creates a striking effect when planted in groups and is well-suited for coastal regions. It also performs excellently in containers. Astelia chathamica is evergreen and native to the Chatham Islands of New Zealand. Learn more about Astelia chathamica.

otherCommonNames: Mountain Astelia, Bush Flax, Bush Lily
description: Astelia nervosa 'Westland' forms clumps and is prized for its ornamental value, with broad, spiky, silver-green leaves that are tinged with red-bronze. It can be grown with ease in areas with full sun or partial shade, and it can adapt to both wet and dry soil conditions. It has a dramatic effect when planted in groups and is also an excellent choice for containers. Astelia nervosa is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Astelia nervosa.

Azara microphylla features branches that arch and bear small, glossy, dark-green leaves. In the spring, it produces small golden-yellow flowers that emit a pleasant vanilla scent. It can be pruned to form a dense screen or trained into an espaliered shape. Azara microphylla is evergreen and native to Chile and Argentina. Learn more about Azara microphylla.

When young, this tree grows upright, but as it ages, it develops a more open form. It grows rapidly and can thrive in coastal environments. Large yellow brush flowers bloom from autumn through spring, attracting tuis and bellbirds. It's an excellent choice for providing shelter and can be pruned into any desired shape or size. Banksia integrifolia is evergreen and native to Australia, occurring between the states of Victoria and Queensland. Learn more about Banksia integrifolia.

Beilschmiedia tarairi stands tall and erect and has smooth brown bark. Its young shoots are covered in fine brown hairs, and its broad olive-green leaves are leathery, heavily-veined, and glossy. It prefers moist soil and can tolerate light to medium frosts. Wood pigeons are fond of this tree's large purple berries, which ripen in autumn. Beilschmiedia tarairi is evergreen and native to the North Island of New Zealand. Learn more about Beilschmiedia tarairi.

Beilschmiedia tawa grows slowly but is long-lasting, and ultimately, it can become a giant in the forest. It grows erect with almost black bark, and its small willowy leaves are pale green and hang in a graceful manner. In the winter, this tree's large purple berries are beloved by wood pigeons. Beilschmiedia tawa is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Beilschmiedia tawa.

Berberis thunbergii f. atropurpurea 'Helmond Pillar' has deep purple to red leaves that retain their color throughout the spring and summer and transition to bright red in the fall. Its tight column of upright stems maintains its shape without the need for trimming. However, the stems are lined with sharp thorns. It's a great option for small or limited spaces. Berberis thunbergii is deciduous and native to Japan and eastern Asia. Learn more about Berberis thunbergii.

Betula costata has gorgeous peeling bark that features cream-white tones with pink-orange hues. It grows upright and has bright green leaves with noticeable veining. In the fall, its leaves turn a vibrant gold color. However, it's not tolerant of drought conditions. Betula costata is deciduous and native to Korea and the Russian Far East in Russia. Learn more about Betula costata.

Betula ermanii is graceful and vigorous, and it has peeling bark that features cream-white tones with pink-orange hues. This gives it a warm glow that stands out among darker evergreen trees, particularly during the winter months. Its bright green leaves turn a vibrant yellow color in the fall. Betula ermanii has a conical, upright-growing habit that broadens with age. Betula ermanii is deciduous and native to Northeast China, Korea, Japan, and the Russian Far East in Russia (Kuril Islands, Sakhalin, Kamchatka). Learn more about Betula ermanii.

This birch tree has a trunk that is pure white and its bark peels. The green leaves of Betula ermanii 'Polar Bear' transition to a buttery yellow color in the fall. Betula ermanii is deciduous and native to Northeast China, Korea, Japan, and the Russian Far East in Russia (Kuril Islands, Sakhalin, Kamchatka). Learn more about Betula ermanii.

Betula nigra is an excellent choice for wet areas and has a strong pyramidal shape. Its peeling bark is pink to orange-brown on younger trees, revealing a lighter cream-white bark underneath. On older trees, the bark becomes red to grey-brown and eventually almost black. Betula nigra's glossy green leaves have a glaucous underside and turn bright yellow in the fall. Betula nigra is deciduous and native to the Eastern United States from New Hampshire west to southern Minnesota, south to northern Florida, and west to Texas. Learn more about Betula nigra.

Betula nigra 'Heritage' has a graceful appearance with its pendant branches. Its shiny, deep-green leaves turn yellow in the autumn, and it bears long and striking male catkins in late winter. Its peeling bark is pink to orange-brown on younger trees, revealing a lighter cream-white bark underneath, while on older trees, the bark becomes red to grey-brown and eventually almost black. Betula nigra 'Heritage' can thrive in both moist and dry areas. Betula nigra is deciduous and native to the Eastern United States from New Hampshire west to southern Minnesota, south to northern Florida, and west to Texas. Learn more about Betula nigra. Betula nigra 'Heritage' was found by Earl Cully growing in St. Louis, Missouri, United States.

Betula nigra 'Summer Cascade' features gently weeping, pendulous branches and pink, peeling bark. Its foliage is dark green during the spring and summer months, but transforms into a stunning yellow color during the autumn. Its peeling bark is pink to orange-brown on younger trees, revealing a lighter cream-white bark underneath, while on older trees, the bark becomes red to grey-brown and eventually almost black. Betula nigra is deciduous and native to the Eastern United States from New Hampshire west to southern Minnesota, south to northern Florida, and west to Texas. Learn more about Betula nigra. Betula nigra 'Summer Cascade' was introduced by John and Daniel Allen of Shiloh Nursery in Harmony, North Carolina, United States.

Betula nigra 'Uru Tawhai' is well-suited for planting in wet areas, and its green leaves transform into a bright yellow color during the fall. Its peeling bark is pink to orange-brown on younger trees, revealing a lighter cream-white bark underneath, while on older trees, the bark becomes red to grey-brown and eventually almost black. Betula nigra is deciduous and native to the Eastern United States from New Hampshire west to southern Minnesota, south to northern Florida, and west to Texas. Learn more about Betula nigra.

This birch is highly regarded for its noticeable white trunk and elegant, drooping young stems. Its glossy green leaves turn yellow during the autumn season. It's particularly lovely when planted in groups. Betula pendula is deciduous and native to Europe and parts of Asia, though in southern Europe, it is only found at higher altitudes. Its range extends into Siberia, China, and southwest Asia in the mountains of northern Turkey, the Caucasus, and northern Iran. Learn more about Betula pendula.

Betula pendula 'Black Prince' has slender, cascading branches that grow in a narrow form. Its rich purple foliage retains its color well throughout the spring and summer. The young branches are purple-black, and this tree has white bark, although it's not as white as that of Betula pendula. It's important to protect this tree from strong winds. Betula pendula is deciduous and native to Europe and parts of Asia, though in southern Europe, it is only found at higher altitudes. Its range extends into Siberia, China, and southwest Asia in the mountains of northern Turkey, the Caucasus, and northern Iran. Learn more about Betula pendula.

Betula pendula 'Dalecarlica' has a similar graceful habit to Betula pendula, but its branches cascade even more. The rich green leaves are deeply cut and serrated, which imparts a light, delicate appearance to this tree. It has white trunks when mature, and its yellow autumn leaves add to its charm. However, it's less tolerant of prolonged dry spells. Betula pendula is deciduous and native to Europe and parts of Asia, though in southern Europe, it is only found at higher altitudes. Its range extends into Siberia, China, and southwest Asia in the mountains of northern Turkey, the Caucasus, and northern Iran. Learn more about Betula pendula. Betula pendula 'Dalecarlica' was discovered in 1767 by Hans Gustaf Hiordt in the village of Ornäs, in the central Swedish province of Dalarna.

This birch tree has a compact, upright growth habit, and its lime-green leaves add a vibrant touch throughout the summer months. Its autumn foliage is a brilliant gold color, while its branch stems transition from golden-orange to pink-red during the winter. Betula pendula 'Wade's Gold' develops very white trunks, which adds to its aesthetic appeal. It's an excellent choice as a street tree. Betula pendula is deciduous and native to Europe and parts of Asia, though in southern Europe, it is only found at higher altitudes. Its range extends into Siberia, China, and southwest Asia in the mountains of northern Turkey, the Caucasus, and northern Iran. Learn more about Betula pendula.

Betula pendula 'Youngii' forms a dome-shaped canopy of slender, drooping side-branches that emerge from a straight trunk. Its small green leaves turn a bright yellow color during the autumn season. Betula pendula is deciduous and native to Europe and parts of Asia, though in southern Europe, it is only found at higher altitudes. Its range extends into Siberia, China, and southwest Asia in the mountains of northern Turkey, the Caucasus, and northern Iran. Learn more about Betula pendula. Betula pendula 'Youngii' was found as a chance seedling trailing on the ground and was introduced by the nursery of Maurice Young in Milford, Surrey, England in about 1874.

synonyms: Betula pendula subsp. mandshurica, Betula platyphylla subsp. mandshurica, Betula mandshurica var. japonica
description: This beautiful birch tree has a slender form similar to that of other birch trees, but its leaves are larger and more substantial. Its leaves turn a bright yellow color in the autumn season. Betula platyphylla var. japonica has very white bark that extends all the way down to the ground, even as it ages. Its leaves are also resistant to rust. Betula platyphylla is deciduous and native to subarctic and temperate Asia in Japan, China, Korea, Mongolia, and the Russian Far East and Siberia. Learn more about Betula platyphylla.

Betula populifolia 'Whitespire' has a narrow growth habit and is an excellent choice as a street tree, for avenues, or in spaces with limited room. Its dazzling white bark is present from ground level and persists even as this tree ages. Its leaves turn a beautiful yellow color during the autumn season. Betula populifolia is deciduous and native to eastern North America. Betula populifolia 'Whitespire' was selected and introduced in 1983 by Edward R. Hasselkus of the University of Wisconsin-Madison, Wisconsin, United States. Learn more about Betula populifolia.

This birch tree is beautiful and features dazzling white peeling bark that extends from top to bottom and remains even as this tree ages. Its growth habit is neat and erect, and its large tapering dark-green leaves turn a bright yellow color during the autumn season. Betula utilis is deciduous and native to the Western Himalayas. Learn more about Betula utilis.

This is a superior variety of Betula utilis subsp. jacquemontii, and it's known for its stunning, snow-white bark. Betula utilis subsp. jacquemontii 'Dazzler' is lovely, with dazzling, peeling bark that extends from top to bottom and persists even as this tree ages. Its growth habit is neat and erect, and its large tapering dark-green leaves turn a bright yellow color during the autumn season. Betula utilis is deciduous and native to the Western Himalayas. Learn more about Betula utilis.

Betula utilis subsp. jacquemontii 'Jermyns' is vigorous and has a broad, conical shape. It features an attractive white bark that peels off in horizontal, papery flakes. Its dark green leaves turn a beautiful golden-yellow color during the autumn season. Betula utilis is deciduous and native to the Western Himalayas. Learn more about Betula utilis. Betula utilis subsp. jacquemontii 'Jermyns' originally came to Messrs Hillier in the United Kingdom from a Belgian nursery as Betula utilis subsp. jacquemontii and were so uniform as to indicate that they had been propagated vegetatively.

Betula utilis subsp. jacquemontii 'Silver Shadow' has a conical crown and features clear white bark on both its trunk and branches. Its oval leaves are dark green and drooping, but turn yellow during the autumn season. The male catkins of Betula utilis subsp. jacquemontii 'Silver Shadow' are noticeable in early spring. Betula utilis is deciduous and native to the Western Himalayas. Learn more about Betula utilis.

Brachychiton acerifolius grows into a tall and stately, upright form with a spreading crown. Its large, glossy, lobed leaves drop in the spring before flowering, which reveals vivid scarlet bells hanging in trusses. Brachychiton acerifolius tends to flower best in hot, dry climates. Brachychiton acerifolius is semi-evergreen and native to tropical and subtropical regions on the east coast of Australia. Learn more about Brachychiton acerifolius.

Brachychiton rupestris has an upright, spreading growth habit and produces panicles of cream-yellow flowers with red markings in the spring season. It has a large, bulbous trunk and is a drought-deciduous succulent, which means it sheds very few leaves. Brachychiton rupestris is semi-evergreen and native to Queensland, Australia. Learn more about Brachychiton rupestris.

Buxus sempervirens 'Graham Blandy' has a tall, columnar growth habit and features shiny, dark green, rounded leaves. It grows slowly and is hardy in both sun and semi-shade. Buxus sempervirens is evergreen and native to western and southern Europe, northwest Africa, and southwest Asia. Learn more about Buxus sempervirens. Buxus sempervirens 'Graham Blandy' was selected from seedlings at the Blandy Experimental Farm in Virginia, United States around 1936 and named by Lynn Batdorf.

Callistemon citrinus produces red flowers during the spring season and may bloom again in the autumn if it's adequately watered. It's suitable for planting in coastal areas and wet sites, and it can also tolerate some dry soils. Callistemon citrinus is evergreen and native to Australia. Learn more about Callistemon citrinus.

Callistemon citrinus 'Red Cluster' has a vigorous, rounded growth habit and produces a profusion of crimson-red brush-like flowers during the spring season, with a second flowering occurring in the autumn. Its flowers are attractive to nectar-seeking birds. Once established, this tree is drought-tolerant. Callistemon citrinus is evergreen and native to Australia. Learn more about Callistemon citrinus.

Callistemon citrinus 'Western Glory' has green, slender, leathery leaves and produces large heads of red-pink flowers in the late spring through to the summer season. Its flowers attract nectar-seeking bees, and this tree is hardy in both coastal and drought conditions. Callistemon citrinus is evergreen and native to Australia. Learn more about Callistemon citrinus. Callistemon citrinus 'Western Glory' was selected from a batch of Callistemon citrinus seedlings about 1980 by George Lullfitz in Wanneroo, Western Australia.

Callistemon 'Hot Pink' is a spreading grower and produces large, bright pink, brush-like flowers during the spring season. Its flowers are attractive to nectar-feeding birds, and this tree is tolerant to both drought and coastal conditions. Callistemon 'Hot Pink' is evergreen and a hybrid between Callistemon citrinus 'Splendens' and Callistemon pallidus. Callistemon 'Hot Pink' was bred in South Africa.

Callistemon 'John Mashlan' has a compact, upright growth habit and produces a profusion of candy-floss pink brush-like flowers during the spring and summer seasons. Once established, this tree is drought-tolerant. Callistemon 'John Mashlan' is evergreen and not native to New Zealand.

Callistemon 'Kings Park Special' is compact and free-flowering, with bright-red flower-heads that bloom during the spring and summer seasons. It's highly adaptable and can thrive in a range of soil types and positions. Callistemon 'Kings Park Special' is well-suited as both a feature or screen plant. Callistemon 'Kings Park Special' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a seedling that was raised at Kings Park and Botanic Garden in Perth, Australia in the 1970s. The original plant was selected and propagated by E. Wittwer. The origin of the seed is not known.

Callistemon salignus features pink-red new foliage and produces beautiful cream-colored bottlebrush flowers throughout the spring, summer, and autumn seasons. It's capable of tolerating waterlogged soils for extended periods, as well as drought conditions. Callistemon salignus is hardy and easy to grow. Callistemon salignus is evergreen and native to eastern Australia. Learn more about Callistemon salignus.

Callistemon viminalis has dark-green leaves and produces deep-red bottlebrush flowers in the late spring through early summer, with some spot-flowering occurring throughout the year. Callistemon viminalis is capable of tolerating wet sites as well as short spells of drought. Callistemon viminalis is evergreen and native to the states of New South Wales, Queensland, and Western Australia in Australia. Learn more about Callistemon viminalis.

Callistemon viminalis 'Macarthur' features a more compact growth habit and improved flower presentation. It has fresh-green, toned foliage with bushy and neat growth, and responds very well to pruning after flowering. Callistemon viminalis 'Macarthur' produces beautiful red flowers for most of the year and is resistant to myrtle rust. Callistemon viminalis is evergreen and native to the states of New South Wales, Queensland, and Western Australia in Australia. Learn more about Callistemon viminalis. Callistemon viminalis 'Macarthur' is a hybrid between Callistemon viminalis 'Little John' and Callistemon viminalis 'Captain Cook'. Callistemon viminalis 'Macarthur' was developed by Ozbreed in Australia.

Callistemon viminalis 'Red Alert' is a unique bottlebrush that produces vivid-red new growth for two months in both the autumn and spring seasons, along with light-red new growth for even more months. It's low-maintenance, drought and frost-tolerant, and thrives in windy conditions, making it suitable for most soils. Callistemon viminalis is evergreen and native to the states of New South Wales, Queensland, and Western Australia in Australia. Learn more about Callistemon viminalis. Callistemon viminalis 'Red Alert' was developed by Ozbreed in Australia.

Callitris rhomboidea grows in a columnar shape and features green, cypress-like foliage. It can be utilized as a specimen, and over time, it forms a beautiful pyramid shape. It's also well-suited for use as a trimmed hedge or screen. During cold weather, the foliage takes on a purple-brown tinge. Callitris rhomboidea is highly resistant to canker. Callitris rhomboidea is evergreen and native to the states of South Australia, Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria, and Tasmania in Australia. Learn more about Callitris rhomboidea.

Camellia 'Ariel's Song' is a bushy grower that produces small, single, white flowers during the spring season. It makes for a great specimen or hedge. Camellia 'Ariel's Song' has an upright, open growth habit with pendulous branches and light-green leaves typically measuring 9cm long by 3cm wide. The flowers are usually 4cm across by 2.5cm deep with five petals, featuring gold anthers on white filaments. Camellia 'Ariel's Song' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Camellia fraterna and Camellia tsaii. Camellia 'Ariel's Song' was produced by A. B. Durrant in Rotorua, New Zealand and first flowered in 1973.

Camellia 'Black Lace' is a formal-looking camellia with large, dark-red, double flowers that bloom during the spring season. It's a compact, upright-grower that's ideal for use as a hedge. Camellia 'Black Lace' features dark-green, glossy leaves, usually measuring 8cm long by 4cm wide. The flowers are typically 11cm wide by 4cm deep, containing 130-140 petals and never showing stamens. Camellia 'Black Lace' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Camellia x williamsii 'Donation' and Camellia x reticulata 'Crimson Robe'. Camellia 'Black Lace' was produced by L. W. Ruffin in Mississippi, United States and first flowered in 1965.

Camellia 'Cinnamon Cindy' produces miniature flowers with a semi-double to rose form. It features a profusion of pink buds that open to pale-pink or white, blooming from late-autumn to early-spring. Camellia 'Cinnamon Cindy' is a strong, upright grower that's excellent for use in narrow spaces. It has light green leaves, usually measuring 5cm long by 2.8cm wide. The flowers are typically 5.3cm wide by 2.5cm deep, containing 18 petals and 22 petaloids, orange anthers, white filaments, and a deep cinnamon fragrance. Camellia 'Cinnamon Cindy' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Camellia japonica 'Kan'yōtai' and Camellia lutchuensis. Camellia 'Cinnamon Cindy' was produced by W. Ackerman in Glendale, Maryland, United States and first flowered in 1967.

Camellia 'Fairy Blush' features a profusion of deep-pink buds that open up to single, white to pale-pink flowers that are blushed pink around the edges. The lightly fragrant flowers are typically 5cm wide by 2cm deep, with yellow anthers on creamy filaments. Camellia 'Fairy Blush' has an upright and open growth habit, with small, dark green leaves that are usually 3cm long by 2cm wide. It blooms from late-autumn to early-spring and is perfect for use as a superb hedge. Camellia 'Fairy Blush' prefers full sun or semi-shade. Camellia 'Fairy Blush' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid of Camellia lutchuensis. Camellia 'Fairy Blush' was produced by M. C. Jury in North Taranaki, New Zealand and first flowered in 1988.

Camellia 'Fairy Wand' features small, semi-double red-pink flowers and has an upright, open growth habit with dark-green leaves, usually measuring 5cm long by 2.5cm wide. It blooms from early-winter through spring, and the flowers are typically 4cm wide by 2.5cm deep, containing 15 petals. Camellia 'Fairy Wand' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Camellia 'Tiny Princess' and the hybrid formed between Camellia saluenensis and Camellia japonica 'Kon-wabisuke' (syn. Camellia japonica 'Fuyajo'). Camellia 'Fairy Wand' was produced by Oswald Blumhardt in Whangārei, New Zealand.

Camellia 'High Fragrance' produces large, peony pink-white flowers that open from salmon-pink buds and exude a delicious, strong fragrance reminiscent of Camellia lutchuensis. Blooming for an extended period from mid-winter through mid-spring, it has an open growth habit with dark-green leaves that typically measure 7.5cm long by 4.5cm wide. The flowers are usually 9-10cm wide by 6.5cm deep, and contain 30 petals, about 10 petaloids, and some stamens with white filaments and yellow anthers. Camellia 'High Fragrance' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Camellia japonica 'Mrs Bertha A. Harms' and the hybrid formed from Camellia 'Salab' and Camellia 'Scentuous'. Camellia 'High Fragrance' was produced by J. R. Finlay in Whangārei, New Zealand and first flowered in 1985.

This is a compact, upright shrub with gracefully hanging branches. It produces small to medium-sized, double to peony flowers in a delicate light-pink shade, each flower having 45 to 50 petals. The flowering period of this shrub is from early autumn to late winter. Camellia japonica is evergreen and native to mainland China, Taiwan, southern Korea, and southwestern Japan. Learn more about Camellia japonica. Camellia japonica 'Ave Maria' was produced by Caesar Breschini in San Jose, California, United States and first flowered in 1953.

synonyms: Camellia japonica 'Sara C. Hastie', Camellia japonica 'French Pink Peony', Camellia japonica 'Wutai Xinxiu'
description: Camellia japonica 'Debutante' has an upright growth habit and produces plenty of sizeable, light-pink flowers in a peony-style from winter to early spring. These blooms create a pleasing contrast with the glossy, dark-green foliage. It's an ideal choice for a hedge or privacy screen, effectively concealing unattractive spaces. The flowers typically measure 8 to 10cm across. Camellia japonica is evergreen and native to mainland China, Taiwan, southern Korea, and southwestern Japan. Learn more about Camellia japonica. Camellia japonica 'Debutante' was produced at the Magnolia Plantation and Gardens, Charleston, South Carolina, United States in the early 1900s.

Camellia japonica 'Kramer's Beauty' is a chance seedling from Camellia japonica 'Kramer's Supreme'. Its deep-red buds unfurl into magnificent, peony-style, rosy-red blooms that emit a delightful fragrance. Against the glossy, dark-green leaves, the flowers create a stunning contrast, illuminating lightly-shaded areas. It flowers from early to late winter and looks stunning in woodland borders, foundation plantings, or as a hedge. With its compact and upright growth habit, it's an excellent choice for various landscaping purposes. Camellia japonica is evergreen and native to mainland China, Taiwan, southern Korea, and southwestern Japan. Learn more about Camellia japonica. Camellia japonica 'Kramer's Beauty' was produced by Kramer Brothers Nurseries in California, United States.

The magnificent peony-style flowers of this tree begin as deep-red buds and open into rosy-red blooms that are complemented by a delightful fragrance. The contrast between the stunning flowers and the glossy, dark-green foliage brightens lightly-shaded areas. Camellia japonica 'Kramer's Supreme' produces flowers from early to late winter, making it a perfect addition to woodland borders and foundation plantings, or as a hedge. Its beauty is sure to impress in any landscaping setting. Camellia japonica is evergreen and native to mainland China, Taiwan, southern Korea, and southwestern Japan. Learn more about Camellia japonica. Camellia japonica 'Kramer's Supreme' was produced by August Kramer of Kramer Brothers Nurseries in California, United States.

Camellia japonica 'Mark Alan' produces large semi-double flowers in a range of rose to wine-red shades from late autumn to late winter, and is known for its abundant blooms. It thrives in full sun or semi-shade and typically produces flowers that are 12.5cm wide by 5cm deep, consisting of 12 to 15 petals and 25 to 30 long, slender petaloids interspersed with yellow stamens. Camellia japonica 'Mark Alan' has an upright and dense growth habit. Camellia japonica is evergreen and native to mainland China, Taiwan, southern Korea, and southwestern Japan. Learn more about Camellia japonica. Camellia japonica 'Mark Alan' was produced by H. E. Ashby in Charleston, South Carolina, United States.

Camellia japonica 'Roger Hall' is known for its beautiful, formal, double, red flowers, which contrast well against its handsome, glossy, green, finely-serrated foliage. It's an outstanding performer that can make a strong statement in either a garden or container. The flowers usually measure 6.5 to 7.5cm wide and appear from late winter to early spring. Camellia japonica 'Roger Hall' thrives in semi-shade and has an upright and dense growth habit, with dark-green leaves that typically measure 9cm long by 4.5cm wide. Camellia japonica is evergreen and native to mainland China, Taiwan, southern Korea, and southwestern Japan. Learn more about Camellia japonica. Camellia japonica 'Roger Hall' was produced by Roger Hall in Tea Tree Gully, South Australia, Australia.

Camellia japonica 'Takanini' features glowing, medium-sized anemone-shaped flowers in a deep-red color with a slight fragrance. It has a strong, bushy, and narrow-growing habit, producing flowers from early winter to late spring. The growth habit of Camellia japonica 'Takanini' is upright, with dark-green leaves that are typically 9cm long by 4cm wide. The flowers are usually 8 to 9cm wide by 3.5cm deep, with 15 petals and 140 to 200 petaloids, occasionally featuring anthers. Camellia japonica is evergreen and native to mainland China, Taiwan, southern Korea, and southwestern Japan. Learn more about Camellia japonica. Camellia japonica 'Takanini' was produced by Neville Haydon in Auckland, New Zealand and first flowered in 1984.

Camellia japonica 'Tom Knudsen' produces dark-red flowers with deeper veining in a peony to double form. The blooms appear from late winter to early spring, and typically measure 11cm wide by 7.5cm deep, with 50 petals and 4 petaloids. Camellia japonica 'Tom Knudsen' has a compact and upright growth habit, with dark-green leaves that usually measure 7.5cm long by 5.5cm wide. Camellia japonica is evergreen and native to mainland China, Taiwan, southern Korea, and southwestern Japan. Learn more about Camellia japonica. Camellia japonica 'Tom Knudsen' was produced by Frank Maitland in Sylmar, California, United States and first flowered in 1956.

Camellia 'Nicky Crisp' produces beautiful semi-double pale-pink flowers from late autumn to mid-spring. The flowers typically measure 11cm wide by 3.5cm deep and consist of 16 petals, cream filaments, and gold anthers. Camellia 'Nicky Crisp' is a compact grower with dark-green leaves that are usually 8.5cm long by 3.5cm wide. Camellia 'Nicky Crisp' is a great choice for pots, planters, and small gardens. Camellia 'Nicky Crisp' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Camellia pitardii and Camellia japonica. Camellia 'Nicky Crisp' was produced by A. B. Durrant in Rotorua, New Zealand and first flowered in 1972.

Camellia 'Ruby Wedding' produces large, bright-red flowers with frilly petals in anemone to peony form. The blooms are typically 8cm wide by 5cm deep and consist of 16 petals, about 137 petaloids, and gold stamens. They are very showy and contrast beautifully against the large, glossy, deep-green leaves, which are usually 9cm long by 5cm wide. Camellia 'Ruby Wedding' flowers from late winter to late spring and has a dense, compact growth habit with a pyramidal form. Camellia 'Ruby Wedding' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Camellia japonica 'Kimberley' and Camellia x williamsii 'Dark Nite'. Camellia 'Ruby Wedding' was produced by Les Jury in New Plymouth, New Zealand and first flowered in 1987.

Camellia sasanqua 'Crimson King' produces large, semi-double, pink-red flowers from early autumn to early winter. The blooms are usually 12cm wide and have attractive golden stamens. Camellia sasanqua 'Crimson King' is a great choice for hedges and screens. Camellia sasanqua is evergreen and native to China and Japan. Learn more about Camellia sasanqua. Camellia sasanqua 'Crimson King' was produced in Japan in the early 1900s.

Camellia sasanqua 'Early Pearly' produces small, formal, double flowers that are white with a hint of pink. The flowers are typically 4cm wide by 1.2cm deep and appear early, from late autumn to mid-winter. Camellia sasanqua 'Early Pearly' has an upright, open growth habit, with dark-green leaves that are usually 2.5cm long by 1.2cm wide. Camellia sasanqua is evergreen and native to China and Japan. Learn more about Camellia sasanqua. Camellia sasanqua 'Early Pearly' was produced by Mervin B. Wine in Thomasville, Georgia, United States and first flowered in 1969.

synonyms: Camellia sasanqua 'White Doves', Camellia sasanqua 'Snow On The Mountain', Camellia sasanqua 'Snow On The Peak', Camellia sasanqua 'Snow', Camellia sasanqua 'Baige', Camellia sasanqua 'Alpine Snow'
description: Camellia sasanqua 'Mine-no-yuki' is known for its elegant, snow-white, double blooms that feature orange anthers and cream filaments scattered among the 3 to 4 tiers of petals. It enjoys an upright, willowy habit, with arching, cascading branches that add to its visual appeal. Camellia sasanqua 'Mine-no-yuki' flowers from early autumn to early winter, offering a beautiful display during this time. Camellia sasanqua is evergreen and native to China and Japan. Learn more about Camellia sasanqua. Camellia sasanqua 'Mine-no-yuki' was produced in Japan.

Camellia sasanqua 'Paradise Blush' produces deep-pink buds that open into stunning semi-double white flowers with a rose-pink blush on the edges. It flowers from early autumn to late winter, adding color and beauty to the garden during the colder months. Camellia sasanqua 'Paradise Blush' has a thick, compact, and upright growth habit, making it a great choice for hedging and screening. Camellia sasanqua is evergreen and native to China and Japan. Learn more about Camellia sasanqua. Camellia sasanqua 'Paradise Blush' was produced by Paradise Plants Nursery in Kulnura, New South Wales, Australia.

Camellia sasanqua 'Paradise Sayaka' is an exquisite cultivar with single to semi-double, white flowers that are broadly edged with soft, salmon-pink. It produces blooms from early autumn to late winter, providing a beautiful display during the colder months. Camellia sasanqua 'Paradise Sayaka' has an upright, dense growth habit, making it an excellent choice for restricted sites where narrow growth is required. Camellia sasanqua is evergreen and native to China and Japan. Learn more about Camellia sasanqua. Camellia sasanqua 'Paradise Sayaka' was produced by Paradise Plants Nursery in Kulnura, New South Wales, Australia.

synonyms: Camellia sasanqua 'Fluted White', Camellia sasanqua 'Wavy White', Camellia sasanqua 'Elegant Friends'
description: Camellia sasanqua 'Setsugekka' produces medium-sized, single to semi-double flowers in pure white with 7 to 12 incurved petals and a slight fragrance. Camellia sasanqua 'Setsugekka' blooms from early autumn to mid-winter, and has an upright, vigorous growth habit with deep-green leaves usually measuring 5 to 7cm long by 2 to 3cm wide. Camellia sasanqua 'Setsugekka' is an excellent choice for hedges, providing a beautiful and fragrant border. Camellia sasanqua is evergreen and native to China and Japan. Learn more about Camellia sasanqua. Camellia sasanqua 'Setsugekka' was produced by Jisuke Minagawa in Japan.

Camellia sasanqua 'Silver Dollar' produces medium-sized, ruffled, double flowers in pure white, which appear in autumn and early winter. Camellia sasanqua 'Silver Dollar' has a slow-growing but dense, upright growth habit, making it an excellent choice for a low hedge. Camellia sasanqua is evergreen and native to China and Japan. Learn more about Camellia sasanqua. Camellia sasanqua 'Silver Dollar' was produced by Nuccio's Nurseries in Altadena, California, United States, first flowered in 1978, and was introduced into commerce in 1985.

Camellia 'Spring Festival' produces pure-pink, double flowers that are typically 5 to 6cm wide. It flowers profusely from mid-winter to early spring, adding color and beauty to the garden during the colder months. Camellia 'Spring Festival' has a narrow, upright growth habit with dense foliage. Camellia 'Spring Festival' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid of Camellia cuspidata. Camellia 'Spring Festival' was produced by Toichi Domoto in Hayward, California, United States and first flowered in 1970.

Camellia transnokoensis is a dense-foliaged bush with an upright growth form, making it an excellent choice for screening. It produces a mass of small, white, single flowers that emerge from pink-red buds and completely cover the bush from late winter to early spring. Camellia transnokoensis is hardy and vigorous, able to thrive in a variety of growing conditions. Camellia transnokoensis is evergreen and native to southeastern China, Taiwan, and the Ryukyu Islands of Japan. Learn more about Camellia transnokoensis.

Camellia 'Transtasman' produces masses of single, white to pale-pink flowers that bloom in winter and spring, opening from pink-red buds. The flowers are slightly fragrant and usually measure 4cm wide by 2cm deep, with six petals. Camellia 'Transtasman' has an upright growth habit with glossy, green leaves that are typically 4.5cm long by 1.8cm wide. Camellia 'Transtasman' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Camellia pitardii and Camellia transnokoensis. Camellia 'Transtasman' was produced by Ray Garnett in Beaumaris, Victoria, Australia and first flowered in 1987.

synonyms: Camellia x vernalis 'Flying Dragon', Camellia x vernalis 'Red Bird', Camellia x vernalis 'Scarlet Bird', Camellia x vernalis 'Scarlet Dragon', Camellia x vernalis 'Fire Dragon'
description: Camellia x vernalis 'Hiryū' produces bright, red-pink, single to semi-double flowers in abundance. It flowers throughout autumn into early winter, providing a colorful display during the colder months. Camellia x vernalis 'Hiryū' is a vigorous and hardy cultivar, making it an excellent choice as a screen or large filler. It grows well in both sun and semi-shade. Camellia x vernalis is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid formed between Camellia sasanqua and Camellia japonica. Learn more about Camellia x vernalis. Camellia x vernalis 'Hiryū' was produced in Japan and imported into the United States in 1906 by E. Fenerosa in Mobile, Alabama, United States.

Camellia x vernalis 'Yuletide' has an upright, compact growth habit with dark-green leaves that are typically 4.5cm long by 2.5cm wide. It produces single, red flowers over a long period, from early winter to early spring. The flowers feature golden anthers and usually measure 7.5cm wide with 5 to 7 petals. Camellia x vernalis is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid formed between Camellia sasanqua and Camellia japonica. Learn more about Camellia x vernalis. Camellia x vernalis 'Yuletide' is a seedling from Camellia x vernalis 'Hiryū', was produced by Nuccio's Nurseries in Altadena, California, United States, and first flowered in 1959.

Camellia x williamsii 'Jury's Yellow' is a compact and erect grower with light-green foliage that usually measures 7cm long by 4cm wide. It produces anemone-form flowers that feature 9 white petals and approximately 50 cream-yellow petaloids in the center. The flowers are typically 8cm wide and appear from late autumn to early spring. Camellia x williamsii is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid formed between Camellia japonica and Camellia saluenensis and was originally bred in 1923 at Caerhays Castle in Cornwall, England by John Charles Williams. Learn more about Camellia x williamsii. Camellia x williamsii 'Jury's Yellow' is a hybrid between Camellia japonica 'Gwenneth Morey' and the hybrid formed between Camellia saluenensis and Camellia japonica 'Edith Linton'. Camellia x williamsii 'Jury's Yellow' was produced by Les Jury in New Plymouth, New Zealand and first flowered in 1971.

Camellia x williamsii 'Les Jury' produces large, double to peony-form, deep crimson-red flowers that are typically 10cm wide by 5cm deep, with 75 or more petals and 10 or more petaloids. It blooms from early to late winter, adding a pop of color during the colder months. Camellia x williamsii 'Les Jury' has an upright growth habit with dark-green leaves that are usually 8cm long by 4cm wide, and makes an excellent hedge plant. Camellia x williamsii is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid formed between Camellia japonica and Camellia saluenensis and was originally bred in 1923 at Caerhays Castle in Cornwall, England by John Charles Williams. Learn more about Camellia x williamsii. Camellia x williamsii 'Les Jury' is a seedling from Camellia x williamsii 'Rendezvous' and was produced by Les Jury in New Plymouth, New Zealand.

Camellia x williamsii 'Super Star' produces pure-white, semi-double flowers in spring that are typically 12cm wide by 6cm deep, with 10 petals, white filaments, and golden anthers. Camellia x williamsii 'Super Star' blooms from early to mid-spring, providing a beautiful display during this time. It has an upright growth habit with green leaves that are usually 9cm long by 4cm wide. Camellia x williamsii is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid formed between Camellia japonica and Camellia saluenensis and was originally bred in 1923 at Caerhays Castle in Cornwall, England by John Charles Williams. Learn more about Camellia x williamsii. Camellia x williamsii 'Super Star' was produced by J. E. Shaw in Waima, Northland, New Zealand and first flowered in 1972.

Camellia x williamsii 'Water Lily' has an upright, compact growth habit with dark-green leaves that are usually 6.5cm long by 4cm wide. It produces double, rose-pink flowers that are typically 11cm wide by 5cm deep with about 50 petals. Camellia x williamsii 'Water Lily' flowers from early autumn to mid-spring, providing a beautiful display during the cooler months. Camellia x williamsii is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid formed between Camellia japonica and Camellia saluenensis and was originally bred in 1923 at Caerhays Castle in Cornwall, England by John Charles Williams. Learn more about Camellia x williamsii. Camellia x williamsii 'Water Lily' was produced by Felix Jury in Waitara, New Zealand.

Carpinus betulus has a strong, pyramidal form when young, which becomes rounded with age. The rich-green leaves are heavily-ribbed and turn yellow in autumn, followed by brown leaves throughout the winter. Carpinus betulus is excellent for use as a hedge, and is very popular for pleaching. Its yellow-green catkins in early to mid-spring are a good source of pollen for bees, making it a great addition to a bee-friendly garden. Carpinus betulus is deciduous and native to Western Asia and central, eastern, and southern Europe, including southern England. Learn more about Carpinus betulus.

Carpinus betulus 'Fastigiata' has an upright, pyramidal form that is quite narrow when young and becomes broader with age. It is an excellent choice as an avenue or street tree, thanks to its attractive appearance and hardiness. Carpinus betulus 'Fastigiata' produces yellow autumn leaves and holds some brown leaves through the winter, although less than Carpinus betulus. Its yellow-green catkins in early to mid-spring are a good source of pollen for bees, making it a great addition to a pollinator-friendly garden. Carpinus betulus is deciduous and native to Western Asia and central, eastern, and southern Europe, including southern England. Learn more about Carpinus betulus. Carpinus betulus 'Fastigiata' has been sold since the 1880s.

Carpinus japonica features beautiful, elongated and corrugated green leaves that are a distinctive feature of this tree. In early spring, yellow-green catkins hang from the branches along with the newly emerging leaves, adding a beautiful display of color. Carpinus japonica also produces yellow autumn leaves, providing additional seasonal interest. Carpinus japonica is deciduous and native to Japan. Learn more about Carpinus japonica.

Carpodetus serratus is an attractive tree with spreading branches and green, marbled, and serrated leaves. It goes through a juvenile phase with divaricating branches and small, rounded leaves. From late spring to early autumn, this tree produces a profusion of small, white flowers, adding to its visual appeal. However, it should be noted that this tree does not tolerate drought or wind well, so care should be taken to ensure it is adequately watered and sheltered. Carpodetus serratus is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Carpodetus serratus.

Castanea sativa forms a tall and stately tree with wide-spreading branches, making it an excellent choice for providing shade in wide, open spaces. Castanea sativa has glossy, deep-green leaves with sharply-toothed margins. In autumn, this tree produces red-brown fruits wrapped in a green, spiky case that add to its visual appeal. Castanea sativa also produces yellow autumn leaves, providing additional seasonal interest. While this tree has both male and female flowers on the same tree, it is mostly self-incompatible, so more than one tree is required for pollination and nut production. Castanea sativa is deciduous and native to Southern Europe and Asia Minor and is found across the Mediterranean region, from the Caspian Sea to the Atlantic Ocean. Learn more about Castanea sativa.

Castanea sativa '1005' is a commercial fruiting cultivar and produces red-brown fruits wrapped in a green, spiky case that ripen in autumn. It is known for being a heavy-cropper, producing a large yield of fruit. Castanea sativa '1005' is a strong, upright-grower and is self-fertile, which means it does not require other trees for pollination. In autumn, this tree also produces yellow leaves, adding to its visual appeal. Castanea sativa is deciduous and native to Southern Europe and Asia Minor and is found across the Mediterranean region, from the Caspian Sea to the Atlantic Ocean. Learn more about Castanea sativa. Castanea sativa '1005' was developed in New Zealand.

Casuarina cunninghamiana is a hardy tree that is suitable for windy, wet, and coastal sites. It is able to withstand the challenging growing conditions of these areas. The foliage of this tree is quite palatable to stock, making it a good choice for livestock grazing areas. Casuarina cunninghamiana is also effective for use as a shelterbelt, providing protection from the wind. In addition, it is useful for soil stabilisation in areas with erosion, making it a versatile and practical choice for a range of growing conditions. Casuarina cunninghamiana is evergreen and native to Australia from Daly River in the Northern Territory, north and east in Queensland, and eastern New South Wales. Learn more about Casuarina cunninghamiana.

Catalpa bignonioides is an upright-growing lawn and avenue tree that has a tropical appearance. Its most notable feature is its big, green, heart-shaped leaves, which give it a distinctive look.
