description: Crataegus x media 'Paul's Scarlet' is upright in growth with a compact, rounded head. It produces impressive double crimson-red flowers that completely cover this tree in late spring. In the fall, this tree produces red fruits that are enjoyed by birds. The tree is an excellent choice for street planting. However, it does not develop any significant autumn color, and its branches have thorns. It is a very tough tree that can grow in almost all conditions. Crataegus x media is a hybrid between Crataegus monogyna and Crataegus laevigata. Crataegus x media is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Crataegus x media. Crataegus x media 'Paul's Scarlet' originated in 1858 as a sport growing on a Crataegus x media 'Rosea Flore Pleno' in the garden of Christopher Boyd near Waltham Cross, England. Crataegus x media 'Paul's Scarlet' was propagated by William Paul and unveiled at the International Horticultural Exhibition of 1866.
tolerates: windy, coastal, drought, heavy-rainfall, light-frosts, heavy-frosts

otherCommonNames: Midland Hawthorn, English Hawthorn, Woodland Hawthorn
synonyms: Crataegus laevigata 'Rosea Flore Pleno', Crataegus laevigata 'Coccinea Flore Pleno', Crataegus x media 'Coccinea Flore Pleno', Crataegus laevigata 'Punicea Flore Pleno', Crataegus x media 'Punicea Flore Pleno'
description: Crataegus x media 'Rosea Flore Pleno' is upright in growth with a compact, rounded head. It produces impressive double salmon-pink flowers that completely cover this tree in late spring. In the fall, this tree produces red fruits that are enjoyed by birds. The tree is an excellent choice for street planting. However, it does not develop any significant autumn color, and its branches have thorns. It is a very tough tree that can grow in almost all conditions. Crataegus x media is a hybrid between Crataegus monogyna and Crataegus laevigata. Crataegus x media is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Crataegus x media. Crataegus x media 'Rosea Flore Pleno' has been in cultivation since before 1832.
tolerates: windy, coastal, drought, heavy-rainfall, light-frosts, heavy-frosts

description: Cryptomeria japonica is fast-growing and quickly becomes a tall, stately tree. Its foliage grows from the ground up, making it an excellent shelter tree. The tree is a lovely and enduring specimen, with a pyramidal form. It is known for being tolerant of strong winds, making it a good choice for planting in areas with harsh weather conditions. Cryptomeria japonica is evergreen and native to Japan. Learn more about Cryptomeria japonica.

Cryptomeria japonica 'Egmont' is a selected form of Cryptomeria japonica with superior form, wind hardiness, and growth rate. It is an excellent option for making a screen or hedge and can be pruned to maintain its shape. The tree is known for being able to tolerate most coastal conditions, except for the most severe. Cryptomeria japonica is evergreen and native to Japan. Learn more about Cryptomeria japonica. Cryptomeria japonica 'Egmont' was developed by Cedar Lodge Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand.

Cunonia capensis produces bronze-red new foliage that matures into a beautiful glossy, dark-green. It bears large, fragrant, white panicles of flowers resembling candles throughout the summer. The tree is an ideal choice for smaller gardens and can be grown in large pots since it does not have an invasive root system. However, it does not like windy conditions or hot and dry weather. The tree prefers a temperate climate that mimics the sheltered forest environment where it occurs naturally. Cunonia capensis is evergreen and native to southern Africa. Learn more about Cunonia capensis.

synonyms: Hesperocyparis arizonica var. glabra 'Blue Ice', Callitropsis arizonica var. glabra 'Blue Ice'
description: This conifer is compact and pyramidal in growth, with smooth, frosted, blue leaves. It is very amenable to pruning and can be trimmed into any desired shape or form. The tree is quick-growing and hardy, withstanding strong winds and drought. It makes an excellent choice for dense shelter. The tree is almost immune to cypress canker, making it a low-maintenance option for gardeners. Cupressus arizonica var. glabra is evergreen and native to a wide area around Sedona, Arizona, United States. Learn more about Cupressus arizonica. Cupressus arizonica var. glabra 'Blue Ice' was discovered as a chance seedling in 1960 by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand and introduced by them into commerce in 1984.

Cupressus cashmeriana's foliage grows in pendulous sprays of blue-green with slender, flattened shoots. Young trees, up to about five years old, have juvenile foliage with soft, needle-like leaves. The tree prefers a warm, sheltered site with regular moisture, but it is still hardy enough to grow in various conditions. Cupressus cashmeriana is evergreen and native to the eastern Himalayas in Bhutan and adjacent areas of Arunachal Pradesh in northeastern India. Learn more about Cupressus cashmeriana.

Cupressus gigantea has a narrow, columnar growth habit with attractive blue-grey foliage. It prefers well-drained soils and is hardy and drought-tolerant, making it a resilient choice for various environments. The tree can also be trimmed into a hedge or a shelter belt. Cupressus gigantea is evergreen and native to southeastern Tibet and China on the Qinghai-Tibetan plateau, particularly in the dry valleys of Nyang River and Yarlung Tsangpo River. Learn more about Cupressus gigantea.

synonyms: x Cupressocyparis leylandii 'Ferndown', x Cuprocyparis leylandii 'Ferndown', x Hesperotropsis leylandii 'Ferndown', Callitropsis x leylandii 'Ferndown'
description: Cupressus x leylandii 'Ferndown' has light-green foliage and grows with a narrow form, featuring pendulous branches. It is a great choice for shelter belts. Cupressus x leylandii is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Hesperocyparis macrocarpa and Callitropsis nootkatensis. Cupressus x leylandii was first hybridised in 1888 at Leighton Hall, which is located to the east of Welshpool in Powys, Wales. Learn more about Cupressus x leylandii. Cupressus x leylandii 'Ferndown' originated in 1940 as a seedling selected from seed collected from a garden near Ferndown, Dorset, United Kingdom. Cupressus x leylandii 'Ferndown' was raised at the nurseries of M. Barthelemy in Stapehill, Wimborne, United Kingdom.

synonyms: x Cupressocyparis leylandii 'Leighton Green', x Cuprocyparis leylandii 'Leighton Green', x Hesperotropsis leylandii 'Leighton Green', Callitropsis x leylandii 'Leighton Green'
description: Cupressus x leylandii 'Leighton Green' is a very fast-growing cultivar with naturally wide-spreading branches. It can be easily pruned into a narrow, dense screen, making it an ideal choice for privacy barriers. The tree always has fresh-green leaves that are soft to the touch. It is tolerant of moderate coastal exposure. Cupressus x leylandii is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Hesperocyparis macrocarpa and Callitropsis nootkatensis. Cupressus x leylandii was first hybridised in 1888 at Leighton Hall, which is located to the east of Welshpool in Powys, Wales. Learn more about Cupressus x leylandii. Cupressus x leylandii 'Leighton Green' originated in 1911 as a seedling selected from seed collected from Leighton Hall, which is located to the east of Welshpool in Powys, Wales.

synonyms: x Cupressocyparis leylandii 'Naylor's Blue', x Cuprocyparis leylandii 'Naylor's Blue', x Hesperotropsis leylandii 'Naylor's Blue', Callitropsis x leylandii 'Naylor's Blue'
description: Cupressus x leylandii 'Naylor's Blue' has attractive blue-green foliage and is an excellent choice for hedging and screening. Its dense growth pattern and attractive foliage make it an ideal choice for creating a natural privacy barrier. Cupressus x leylandii is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Hesperocyparis macrocarpa and Callitropsis nootkatensis. Cupressus x leylandii was first hybridised in 1888 at Leighton Hall, which is located to the east of Welshpool in Powys, Wales. Learn more about Cupressus x leylandii. Cupressus x leylandii 'Naylor's Blue' originated in 1911 as a seedling selected from seed collected from Leighton Hall, which is located to the east of Welshpool in Powys, Wales.

synonyms: x Cupressocyparis leylandii 'Stapehill', x Cuprocyparis leylandii 'Stapehill', x Hesperotropsis leylandii 'Stapehill', Callitropsis x leylandii 'Stapehill'
description: Cupressus x leylandii 'Stapehill' has light-green foliage and grows with a narrow form, featuring a lightly-branched structure. It is a great choice for shelter belts and hedges due to its dense growth and narrow habit. Cupressus x leylandii is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Hesperocyparis macrocarpa and Callitropsis nootkatensis. Cupressus x leylandii was first hybridised in 1888 at Leighton Hall, which is located to the east of Welshpool in Powys, Wales. Learn more about Cupressus x leylandii. Cupressus x leylandii 'Stapehill' originated in 1940 as a seedling selected from seed collected from a garden near Ferndown, Dorset, United Kingdom. Cupressus x leylandii 'Stapehill' was raised at the nurseries of M. Barthelemy in Stapehill, Wimborne, United Kingdom.

Cupressus x ovensii grows well in warmer areas and is a fast-growing variety with naturally wide-spreading branches. It can be easily pruned into a narrow, dense screen, making it a popular choice for privacy barriers. The tree always has fresh-green leaves that are soft to the touch. It is tolerant of strong winds, but not coastal winds, and has better canker resistance compared to Cupressus x leylandii cultivars. Cupressus x ovensii is evergreen and a hybrid between Callitropsis nootkatensis and Cupressus lusitanica. Cupressus x ovensii was raised by Howard Ovens at Tan-Y-Cae, Bethel, Caernarfon, United Kingdom from seeds collected in 1961 from Westonbirt, United Kingdom. Learn more about Cupressus x ovensii.

Cupressus sempervirens is a beautiful upright, columnar variety with green to blue-green foliage. It prefers hot, dry climates and well-drained soils, and once established, it is drought-tolerant. Cupressus sempervirens is evergreen and native to the eastern Mediterranean. Learn more about Cupressus sempervirens.

The foliage of Cupressus sempervirens 'Gracilis' is more refined and threadlike, with a fresh-green color. It grows to a tapering point, giving it a distinctive appearance. The tree prefers to grow in well-drained soil and can thrive in both sun or semi-shade environments. Cupressus sempervirens is evergreen and native to the eastern Mediterranean. Learn more about Cupressus sempervirens. Cupressus sempervirens 'Gracilis' was developed in New Zealand.

Cupressus sempervirens 'Stricta' is an upright cultivar that forms a narrow column of blue-green. Occasional pruning will help to maintain its shape and appearance. The tree is tolerant of coastal conditions, drought, and wind, making it a good choice for planting in harsher environments. Cupressus sempervirens is evergreen and native to the eastern Mediterranean. Learn more about Cupressus sempervirens.

Cupressus sempervirens 'Swane's Gold' is a slender, erect, conical variety with golden leaves. It always retains its form, and it does not require pruning or tying to maintain its shape. Cupressus sempervirens is evergreen and native to the eastern Mediterranean. Learn more about Cupressus sempervirens. Cupressus sempervirens 'Swane's Gold' originated in 1944 as a seedling sourced from a Cupressus sempervirens 'Stricta' at the Swane Brothers Nursery in New South Wales, Australia. Cupressus sempervirens 'Swane's Gold' was introduced into commerce in 1956 and was patented in the United States in 1976 (USPP3839).

Cupressus sempervirens 'Totem' is characterized by its slender, erect form and deep-green leaves. It is a striking choice for gardeners who want to add some upright greenery to their landscape. Cupressus sempervirens is evergreen and native to the eastern Mediterranean. Learn more about Cupressus sempervirens. Cupressus sempervirens 'Totem' originated as a seedling around 1984 in New Zealand.

Cupressus torulosa is an upright grower with green to blue-green foliage. It has good tolerance to cypress canker and is an excellent choice for shelter belts where trimming is difficult or not possible. It can also be used for hedging. The tree prefers to grow in free-draining soil. Cupressus torulosa is evergreen and native to the mountainous northern regions of the Indian subcontinent, primarily the Himalayas. Learn more about Cupressus torulosa.

otherCommonNames: Gully Tree Fern, Slender Tree Fern
description: Cyathea cunninghamii is a slender-trunked grower, similar to Cyathea smithii, but when mature, it has a clean trunk without the skirt of dead frond stalks seen on Cyathea smithii. It naturally grows in damp forest areas, particularly in stream gullies and riverbanks. However, it has a lower tolerance for drought than other tree fern species, and it prefers to grow in moist environments. Cyathea cunninghamii is evergreen and native to New Zealand in the North Island, South Island, and Chatham Islands and also to the states of Victoria, New South Wales, Queensland, and Tasmania in Australia. Learn more about Cyathea cunninghamii.

Cyathea dealbata is easily distinguished by the silver-white undersides of mature fronds. It naturally grows in lowland and hill country forests up to about 700m altitude. The tree tolerates drought better than most other tree ferns and enjoys warm summers but prefers to grow in moist soils. It will only tolerate light frosts and does not tolerate strong winds, so it's best to plant it in a sheltered spot. Cyathea dealbata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Cyathea dealbata.

Cyathea medullaris is the tallest-growing of New Zealand's tree ferns and is characterized by its distinctive tall, black trunk. The tree prefers moisture-rich soil and shelter from wind. It naturally grows in lowland and hilly forest terrain up to about 600m altitude and on partially open sites throughout the country. However, it does not tolerate heavy frosts, major drought, or strong winds. The tree has a very wide, almost horizontal, frond spread (about 10m to 14m when fully grown), making it best for larger gardens. Cyathea medullaris is evergreen and native to New Zealand in the North Island, South Island, and Chatham Islands and also in Fiji, the Marquesas Islands, Pitcairn Island, Society Island, and Tubuai Island. Learn more about Cyathea medullaris.

Cyathea smithii is the most tolerant of cold temperatures among tree ferns and is characterized by its thin and soft fronds. It has a skirt of dead frond stalks on its trunk, which is a defining characteristic of this tree. Cyathea smithii is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Cyathea smithii.

Cycas revoluta is frost-tender and slow-growing. Its leaves are a deep, semi-gloss green and grow out into a feather-like rosette, with small protective barbs that should be avoided. Cycas revoluta is evergreen and native to southern Japan. Learn more about Cycas revoluta.

This is an attractive fruiting tree with large, pale-green fruit that ripen to a soft yellow when fully mature. The white flesh has a slight pineapple taste and tastes best when cooked or mixed with other fruit. The tree is hardy and tolerant, but it thrives best in full sun. It typically fruits from mid-autumn through to early-winter, and its pink buds open to white flowers in mid to late-spring. It is self-fertile, so it doesn't need another tree for pollination. Cydonia oblonga is deciduous and native to the Hyrcanian forest region south of the Caspian Sea. Learn more about Cydonia oblonga. Cydonia oblonga 'Pineapple' was developed in the late 1800s by Luther Burbank (1849-1926) in Santa Rosa, California, United States.

This is a moderately vigorous fruit tree that produces large, furrowed, oblong to pear-shaped, golden-yellow, and very aromatic fruit. The flesh is mild, tender, and light-yellow, and the fruit keeps very well. The tree has unusually large leaves, and it typically fruits from mid-autumn through to early-winter. Its pink buds open to white flowers in mid to late-spring, and this tree is self-fertile, so it doesn't require another tree for pollination. Cydonia oblonga is deciduous and native to the Hyrcanian forest region south of the Caspian Sea. Learn more about Cydonia oblonga. Cydonia oblonga 'Smyrna' was developed in Turkey.

This fruit tree produces aromatic, yellow-skinned fruit with lemon-coloured flesh, which can be used for making cider, jams, and preserves. The tree is tolerant and easy to grow in a sunny spot, and it typically fruits from mid-autumn through to early-winter. Its pink buds open to white flowers in mid to late-spring, and this tree is self-fertile and disease-resistant, so it doesn't require another tree for pollination and is less susceptible to diseases. Cydonia oblonga is deciduous and native to the Hyrcanian forest region south of the Caspian Sea. Learn more about Cydonia oblonga. Cydonia oblonga 'Taihape' was developed from an old tree growing at the Brown Sugar Cafe in Taihape, New Zealand.

This is a handsome, narrow-growing tree with semi-weeping branches and soft-green leaves. The juvenile foliage is brown before turning green. It prefers moist situations next to streams, lakes, and ponds, and produces yellow-green catkins in mid-spring to mid-summer, which are a source of pollen for bees. The tree also produces orange-red fruit, which grow under a purple-black seed from mid-summer to mid-autumn and are a great source of food for birds. Dacrycarpus dacrydioides is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Dacrycarpus dacrydioides.

Dacrydium cupressinum is a slow-growing species that can be easily planted in a home garden for up to fifty years. When young, it has a pyramidal crown and drooping branches, but as it matures, it develops a round-topped crown with sturdy lateral branches that carry drooping twigs and leaves. During winter, the foliage of young trees may turn bronze, but in spring, it returns to its green color. In mid-spring to mid-summer, this tree produces green catkins that are a good source of pollen for bees. From mid-summer to mid-autumn, this tree bears orange-red fruit that grows under a purple-black seed, but the seed is only produced every few years. Dacrydium cupressinum is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Dacrydium cupressinum.

Daphniphyllum macropodum has glossy, dark-green leaves resembling those of rhododendrons, which typically hang down during the winter months, exposing the bright-red leaf stalks on new growth. In the spring, new growth appears in a pale-green hue, sometimes tinged with pink. Male flowers, which are purple-pink, and female flowers, which are pale-green, are produced by separate plants in late spring. Once pollinated, the female plants produce blue-black berries in the autumn season. Daphniphyllum macropodum is evergreen and native to China, Japan, and Korea. Learn more about Daphniphyllum macropodum.

Davidia involucrata is an impressive specimen, with sturdy branches and a rounded crown that exudes a stately presence. It produces extraordinary white flowers that look like fluttering handkerchiefs in late spring, hanging gracefully beneath the beautifully ribbed leaves. It's advisable to shelter this tree from strong winds. In some instances, this tree produces shades of orange and red during the autumn season. Davidia involucrata is deciduous and native to South Central and Southeast China. Learn more about Davidia involucrata.

Dicksonia fibrosa has a red-brown, fibrous trunk that is frequently accompanied by a tidy cluster of dead fronds at its base. Its crown is cone-shaped but inverted. It has the ability to withstand both sun and shade, as well as moderate levels of frost, wind, and drought. Dicksonia fibrosa is indigenous to lowland and hill areas located south of the central North Island and can typically be found at elevations of up to approximately 800m. Dicksonia fibrosa is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Dicksonia fibrosa.

Dicksonia squarrosa is known for its resilience among tree ferns, being able to tolerate some full sun (excluding strong afternoon sun during the warmer months), drier soils, and light winds. Additionally, it can withstand moderate frosts. Dicksonia squarrosa has a black trunk, and its crown is flatter, with shorter leaf fronds, making it ideal for smaller gardens. Dicksonia squarrosa is typically found in lowland and hill forests across the country, including Stewart Island, Chatham Island, and Three Kings Islands, at elevations of up to around 800m. Dicksonia squarrosa is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Dicksonia squarrosa.

Dysoxylum spectabile is an attractive, erect species that is well-suited for coastal areas with windy conditions, although it requires good soil and protection from frost. It produces scented white flowers in panicles from early autumn to mid-winter, which add to its visual appeal. The tree also has large, glossy green leaves, which further enhance its beauty. Dysoxylum spectabile is correctly known as Didymocheton spectabilis, but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Didymocheton spectabilis is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Didymocheton spectabilis.

Dodonaea viscosa is a fast-growing, erect species that forms a bushy structure from the ground up. Its long, narrow leaves are a pale-green color. The tree produces yellow-green to red-green flowers from late winter to mid-summer. It is an incredibly resilient species, capable of tolerating sub-zero temperatures, salt-laden winds, drought, and polluted atmospheres. As such, it is well-suited for screening and erosion control purposes. Dodonaea viscosa is evergreen and native to tropical, subtropical, and warm temperate regions of Africa, the Americas, southern Asia, and Australasia. Learn more about Dodonaea viscosa.

Dodonaea viscosa 'Purpurea' is a fast-growing, upright cultivar that forms a bushy structure from the ground up. Its long, narrow leaves are a striking purple-bronze color. The tree is incredibly resilient, capable of tolerating sub-zero temperatures, salt-laden winds, drought, and polluted atmospheres. It produces yellow-green to red-green flowers from late winter to mid-summer, further adding to its ornamental value. Dodonaea viscosa is evergreen and native to tropical, subtropical, and warm temperate regions of Africa, the Americas, southern Asia, and Australasia. Learn more about Dodonaea viscosa. Dodonaea viscosa 'Purpurea' was discovered by Thomas Wilkins in the early 1890s growing along the Wairau River in Malborough, New Zealand.

This bamboo is a dense, clump-forming species that has long, arching canes and light-green foliage. It prefers moist, well-drained soil, and it is advisable to shelter this tree from strong winds to prevent damage. Drepanostachyum falcatum is evergreen and native to Cambodia, Laos, Nepal, Vietnam, and the West Himalayas. Learn more about Drepanostachyum falcatum.

The leaves of this tree are green with silver-grey spots when young, but they turn into a dark-green color with silver-grey undersides as they mature. This tough and fast-growing plant is ideal for hedging and screening, and it is well-suited to tolerate both drought and salt-laden winds. It can be grown in either sun or shade and is known to produce highly fragrant and sweet-scented white flowers in autumn, which are then followed by orange berries in the winter. Overall, this tree makes for a very robust and resilient hedge. Elaeagnus x submacrophylla is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Elaeagnus macrophylla and Elaeagnus pungens. Elaeagnus x submacrophylla was first discovered in 1929 by Simon Doorenbos, the director of the Parks Department in The Hague, Netherlands. Simon sowed seed from several Elaeagnus species next to each other, and from these arose the hybrid Elaeagnus x submacrophylla.

Eriobotrya japonica produces clusters of small, white flowers during the winter season. It also bears yellow-orange fruit that ripen from early spring to early summer, with a sweet-tart flavor resembling that of a plum or cherry. Eriobotrya japonica prefers moist, well-drained soil in full sun, but it can tolerate partial shade. Once established, it can withstand drought conditions. Additionally, this tree is self-fertile. Eriobotrya japonica is evergreen and native to China. Learn more about Eriobotrya japonica.

This coastal-hardy tree produces sweet, easy-to-peel fruit with yellow-orange skin and yellow flesh that ripens in early summer, resembling apricots in flavor. The tree is well-suited for large containers and can thrive in gardens of all sizes. Additionally, this tree is self-fertile, meaning that it can produce fruit without the need for cross-pollination. Eriobotrya japonica is evergreen and native to China. Learn more about Eriobotrya japonica.

Eucalyptus cinerea is both an attractive ornamental and a shelter species. Its juvenile trees have rounded silvery blue-green leaves, while mature trees have long leaves. The tree is capable of tolerating dry soils and coastal exposure, making it a versatile choice for a range of environments. Eucalyptus cinerea is evergreen and native to Australia. Learn more about Eucalyptus cinerea.

Eucalyptus crenulata boasts attractive, silver, egg-shaped to heart-shaped leaves with serrated edges, which are frequently used in cut-flower arrangements. It also produces clusters of cream-white flowers in the spring. Eucalyptus crenulata is versatile and can thrive in both wet and dry conditions. Eucalyptus crenulata is evergreen and native to a small area in Victoria, Australia. Only two natural populations are known, one growing near the Acheron River valley near Buxton, and the other on the Yarra River floodplain in Yering. Learn more about Eucalyptus crenulata.

Eucalyptus johnstonii has thick, dark-green leaves and its bark is a distinctive yellow-green color. It is capable of growing in wet areas and can also tolerate drought conditions. Additionally, this tree is known for its fast growth rate. Eucalyptus johnstonii is evergreen and native to Tasmania, Australia. Learn more about Eucalyptus johnstonii.

Eucalyptus leucoxylon 'Rosea' is one of the hardiest varieties of gums and is capable of tolerating extreme drought and cold conditions. Its adult leaves are long and have a grey-green coloration. In the autumn and winter months, this tree produces a profusion of deep-pink to red flowers that hang from its branches. These flowers are a valuable nectar source for a range of bird species, including tuis, bellbirds, and wax-eyes. The tree is also tall and erect in its growth habit. Eucalyptus leucoxylon is evergreen and native to Australia. Learn more about Eucalyptus leucoxylon. The origin of Eucalyptus leucoxylon 'Rosea' is not known.

Eucalyptus nicholii is a graceful species with narrow, light-green to blue-green leaves that emit a peppermint fragrance when crushed. It is an excellent choice for providing shade and screening, and is able to tolerate both frosts and drought conditions. Eucalyptus nicholii is evergreen and native to New South Wales, Australia. Learn more about Eucalyptus nicholii.

Eucalyptus sideroxylon is fast-growing and has distinct red-brown to black bark. It is prized for its high-quality wood, which is incredibly strong and durable and is used for a variety of purposes. Eucalyptus sideroxylon is capable of tolerating drought conditions and is also able to grow in wet areas. Eucalyptus sideroxylon is evergreen and native to Australia. Learn more about Eucalyptus sideroxylon.

Eucryphia cordifolia has a broad, columnar growth habit and produces beautiful white flowers that bloom from late summer into autumn. Eucryphia cordifolia is evergreen and native to Chile and Argentina. Learn more about Eucryphia cordifolia.

Eucryphia moorei is an erect grower with beautiful pinnate leaves. In the late summer, it bears large, fragrant, single white blossoms. It is an excellent choice for smaller gardens or as a street tree. Eucryphia moorei is evergreen and native to Australia. Learn more about Eucryphia moorei.

Eucryphia x nymansensis 'Nymansay' is an erect grower with larger leaves and very large, pure-white, fragrant blossoms. It blooms from late summer to autumn and prefers cooler growing areas. Eucryphia x nymansensis is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Eucryphia cordifolia and Eucryphia glutinosa. Eucryphia x nymansensis arose from a batch of garden-origin seed that was sown in 1914 at the Nymans garden in West Sussex, England. Eucryphia x nymansensis 'Nymansay' was one of these seedlings. Learn more about Eucryphia x nymansensis.

Fagus sylvatica is a tall and dense species with a pyramidal shape, and its lower branches sweep down to the ground. Its new green leaves have a silky sheen, while the autumn leaves turn yellow, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. The tree is a popular choice for hedging and pleaching. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica.

Fagus sylvatica 'Dawyck Gold' is a tall, columnar cultivar that broadens as it matures. Its bright, golden-yellow leaves have a shiny sheen in the spring, and it has green-yellow leaves throughout the summer. During the autumn season, the leaves turn yellow, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. The tree is ideal for use in limited space and makes an excellent choice as a street tree. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Dawyck Gold' is a seedling of Fagus sylvatica 'Dawyck Green' that was raised in 1968 by Dick van Hoey-Smith at the Trompenburg Arboretum in Rotterdam, Netherlands.

Fagus sylvatica 'Dawyck Green' is a tall, columnar cultivar that broadens as it matures. Its deep-green leaves have a bronze tinge and shiny sheen in the spring, and it has deep-green leaves throughout the summer. During the autumn season, the leaves turn yellow, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. The tree is an excellent choice for use in limited space and is ideal as a street tree. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Dawyck Green' was discovered by John Naesmyth at the Dawyck House in Stobo, Scotland in the early 1800s. The original tree still stands at the rear of the house on the boundary with the Dawyck Botanic Garden.

Fagus sylvatica 'Dawyck Purple' is a tall, columnar cultivar that retains its narrow form. Its deep purple-red spring leaves have a shiny sheen and it maintains its purple leaves throughout the summer. During the autumn season, the leaves turn purple, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. The tree is an excellent choice for use in limited space and is ideal as a street tree. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Dawyck Purple' is a seedling of Fagus sylvatica 'Dawyck Green' that was raised in 1968 by Dick van Hoey-Smith at the Trompenburg Arboretum in Rotterdam, Netherlands.

synonyms: Fagus sylvatica 'Luteovariegata', Fagus sylvatica 'Aureo-variegata', Fagus sylvatica 'Aureovariegata', Fagus sylvatica 'Aurea Variegata', Fagus sylvatica f. luteo-variegata
description: Fagus sylvatica 'Luteo-variegata' is a tall, dense, pyramidal species with lower branches that sweep down to the ground. Its green leaves have yellow-green variegations, and the autumn leaves turn yellow, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. The tree is hardy and able to withstand challenging growing conditions. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Luteo-variegata' has been known in England since about 1770.

Fagus sylvatica 'Pendula' forms a tall, narrow, and magnificent tree with arching side branches that weep down to the ground. It has glossy light-green leaves, and its autumn leaves turn yellow, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Pendula' has been extensively planted for over 200 years and was introduced to North America before 1834.

Fagus sylvatica 'Purple Fountain' grows into a columnar form with cascading side branches. It produces red new leaves in the spring that deepen to purple by summer. During the autumn season, the leaves turn purple, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Purple Fountain' is a seedling of Fagus sylvatica 'Purpurea Pendula' that was discovered in the 1960s in the Netherlands and has been in North American commerce since about 1983.

Fagus sylvatica 'Purpurea' forms a tall, dense, pyramidal tree with lower branches that sweep down to the ground. Its new spring leaves are copper-red with a silky sheen, while its summer leaves are deep-purple. During the autumn season, the leaves turn purple, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Purpurea' has been cultivated for hundreds of years, and the oldest recorded discovery is from a work dated 1680 where Fagus sylvatica 'Purpurea' was discovered in Buchs, Zürich, Switzerland.

Fagus sylvatica 'Purpurea Pendula' has an amazing form that creates a mushroom-shaped dome. Its foliage is a deep-purple in the spring, which turns to purple-green later in the summer. During the autumn season, the leaves turn purple, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Purpurea Pendula' was introduced into commerce around 1865.

Fagus sylvatica 'Red Obelisk' has a narrow, upright form and produces rich purple leaves on a columnar growing tree. During the autumn season, the leaves turn purple, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Red Obelisk' was developed by Dick van Hoey-Smith in the Netherlands by crossing Fagus sylvatica 'Rohanii' with Fagus sylvatica 'Dawyck Green'.

Fagus sylvatica 'Riversii' is a large, dome-shaped tree with an open branch structure and smooth grey bark. It produces larger leaves than the usual purple beech and has rich, deep, purple, shiny leaves in the spring that maintain their color throughout the summer. During the autumn season, the leaves turn purple, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. Fagus sylvatica 'Riversii' is a magnificent specimen tree. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Riversii' was first listed in the catalogues of the Rivers nursery in Sawbridgeworth, United Kingdom in the 1870s.

Fagus sylvatica 'Rohanii' is a tall, dense, pyramidal tree with lower branches that sweep down to the ground and has smooth grey bark. Its spring leaves are a deep red-purple with a silky sheen and become dark-purple by summer. The striking feature of this tree is the deeply-lobed, decorative, oak-like leaves. During the autumn season, the leaves turn purple, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Rohanii' was developed by V. Mašek in 1894 on the estate of Prince Camille de Rohan in Sychrov, Bohemia (now in the Czech Republic).

Fagus sylvatica 'Swat Margaret' produces new leaves that unfold as red-purple and turn dark-purple in the summer. During the autumn season, the leaves turn purple, then brown through the winter and fall off prior to the emergence of new leaves. Fagus sylvatica 'Swat Margaret' tends to hold its purple coloring later into autumn compared to other cultivars. Fagus sylvatica is deciduous and native to Europe. Learn more about Fagus sylvatica. Fagus sylvatica 'Swat Margaret' was raised in Germany in the 1880s by Timm and Co., and was introduced into commerce in 1895.

Feijoa sellowiana 'Apollo' produces medium to large fruit with thin and smooth skin in mid-autumn. The fruit is subject to bruising and purpling, but the pulp is well-developed and slightly gritty. The flavor is very pleasant, and the quality is excellent. It also produces beautiful red flowers from late-spring to mid-summer. Feijoa sellowiana 'Apollo' has an upright and spreading growth habit and is both vigorous and productive. It is coastal and wind-hardy, making it an excellent choice for hedges and screens. While it is partially self-fertile, better crops are achieved when planted with any other feijoa cultivar. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana. Feijoa sellowiana 'Apollo' was developed by Hayward Wright in New Zealand (PVR 176).

Feijoa sellowiana 'Den's Choice' produces medium to large fruit with outstanding flavor, typically harvested in mid to late-autumn. It also produces beautiful red flowers from late-spring to mid-summer. Feijoa sellowiana 'Den's Choice' is coastal and wind-hardy, making it an excellent choice for hedges and screens. It is partially self-fertile, but better crops are achieved when planted with any other feijoa cultivar. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana. Feijoa sellowiana 'Den's Choice' was developed by Dennis Barton in New Zealand.

Feijoa sellowiana 'Gemini' is a high-yielding cultivar with an upright, spreading growth habit. It produces small to medium-sized, oval-shaped fruit with very smooth, thin skin and excellent flavor and texture, typically harvested in early-autumn. Feijoa sellowiana 'Gemini' also produces beautiful red flowers from late-spring to mid-summer. It is coastal and wind-hardy, making it an excellent choice for hedges and screens. While it is partially self-fertile, better crops are achieved when planted with any other feijoa cultivar. For optimal growth, plant in a sunny position with free-draining soil. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana. Feijoa sellowiana 'Gemini' was developed by HortResearch in Havelock North, New Zealand (PVR 175).

Feijoa sellowiana 'Golden Goose' produces large to extra-large fruit with smooth, thick, gold-green skin and sweet, golden-yellow flesh. The fruit is typically harvested from late-autumn to early-winter and has an extra-long shelf-life. Feijoa sellowiana 'Golden Goose' has a rounded, bushy growth habit and produces beautiful red flowers from late-spring to mid-summer. It is coastal and wind-hardy, making it an excellent choice for hedges and screens. While it is partially self-fertile, better crops are achieved when planted with any other feijoa cultivar. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana. Feijoa sellowiana 'Golden Goose' was developed by Tharfield Nursery in Katikati, New Zealand.

Feijoa sellowiana 'Kaiteri' is known for producing exceptionally sweet, tasty, and large to extra-large fruit typically harvested in early to mid-autumn. It also produces beautiful red flowers from late-spring to mid-summer. Feijoa sellowiana 'Kaiteri' is coastal and wind-hardy, making it an excellent choice for hedges and screens. While it is partially self-fertile, better crops are achieved when planted with any other feijoa cultivar. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana. Feijoa sellowiana 'Kaiteri' was developed by Roy Hart in Motueka, New Zealand (PVR 3128).

Feijoa sellowiana 'Kākāriki' produces large and very sweet fruit that is typically harvested in early to mid-autumn. It also produces beautiful red flowers from late-spring to mid-summer. Feijoa sellowiana 'Kākāriki' is coastal and wind-hardy, making it an excellent choice for hedges and screens. While it is partially self-fertile, better crops are achieved when planted with any other feijoa cultivar. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana. Feijoa sellowiana 'Kākāriki' was developed by Roy Hart in Motueka, New Zealand (PVR 3129).

Feijoa sellowiana 'Mammoth' produces medium to large-sized fruit with sweet, soft, juicy, and slightly gritty pulp. It is a strong-growing plant that forms a large bush and typically fruits from late-autumn to early-winter. It also produces beautiful red flowers from late-spring to mid-summer. Feijoa sellowiana 'Mammoth' is coastal and wind-hardy, making it an excellent choice for hedges and screens. While it is partially self-fertile, better crops are achieved when planted with any other feijoa cultivar. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana. Feijoa sellowiana 'Mammoth' was developed by Hayward Wright in New Zealand.

Feijoa sellowiana 'Opal Star' has a compact, upright growth habit and produces medium to large-sized fruit with thin, smooth skin and abundant sweet and juicy pulp. The fruit is typically harvested from mid to late-autumn. It also produces beautiful red flowers from late-spring to mid-summer. Feijoa sellowiana 'Opal Star' is coastal and wind-hardy, making it an excellent choice for hedges and screens. While it is partially self-fertile, better crops are achieved when planted with any other feijoa cultivar. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana. Feijoa sellowiana 'Opal Star' was developed by Tharfield Nursery in Katikati, New Zealand (PVR 734).

Feijoa sellowiana 'Pounamu' produces medium-sized fruit with sweet and juicy flesh that has a rich flavour. The fruit has a dark-green skin and is high-yielding, fruiting in mid-autumn. In addition, this tree produces beautiful red flowers from late-spring to mid-summer. It is also coastal and wind-hardy, making it an excellent choice for hedges and screens. While it is partially self-fertile, it produces better crops when planted with any other feijoa cultivar. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana.

The fruit of this tree, which ripen in early autumn, have a delicious tropical flavor and are quite sizable. It is particularly well-suited for cultivation in colder regions with marginal growing conditions, as it is a hardy and vigorous grower. Additionally, it produces beautiful red flowers from late spring to midsummer and is well-adapted to coastal and windy environments, making it an excellent choice for hedges and screens. While it is partially self-fertile, it will produce better crops when planted alongside another feijoa cultivar. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana. Feijoa sellowiana 'Takaka' was developed by Roy Hart in Motueka, New Zealand (PVR 31025).

The fruit of this tree are medium-sized, with a rough skin and rounded shape. The pulp is slightly gritty, juicy, and soft, and has a mildly aromatic flavor. The fruit ripen in early winter and are accompanied by beautiful red flowers that bloom from late spring to mid-summer. Feijoa sellowiana 'Triumph' is well-suited for coastal and windy environments and can be used to create attractive hedges and screens. While it is partially self-fertile, it will produce better crops when planted alongside another feijoa cultivar. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana. Feijoa sellowiana 'Triumph' was developed by Hayward Wright in New Zealand.

Feijoa sellowiana 'Unique' produces medium-sized, smooth-skinned, light-green fruit with a delicate, juicy flavor. It is a compact grower and the fruit ripen in mid-autumn. Additionally, it boasts beautiful red flowers that bloom from late spring to mid-summer. It is well-suited for coastal and windy environments and can be used to create attractive hedges and screens. Unlike some other feijoa cultivars, it is self-fertile and does not require a pollinator to produce fruit. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana. Feijoa sellowiana 'Unique' was developed by Dennis Barton in New Zealand. Dennis came across Feijoa sellowiana 'Unique' as a seedling in a Tauranga orchard. He trialed this tree before releasing it in 1982 (PVR 165).

description: This feijoa cultivar produces huge, sweet, and meaty fruit with rough, thick skin on a dwarf-growing tree. The fruit has a firm pulp and a strong flavor, and it keeps well. The fruit ripen from mid to late autumn and are accompanied by beautiful red flowers that bloom from late spring to mid-summer. Feijoa sellowiana 'Wiki Tu' is well-suited for coastal and windy environments and can be used to create attractive hedges and screens. While it is partially self-fertile, it will produce better crops when planted alongside another feijoa cultivar. Feijoa sellowiana is evergreen and native to the highlands of southern Brazil, eastern Paraguay, Uruguay, northern Argentina, and Colombia. Learn more about Feijoa sellowiana. Feijoa sellowiana 'Wiki Tu' was developed by P. and G. Gardener in Ruakākā, New Zealand (PVR 723).

This versatile fig tree is well-suited for coastal and drought-prone regions, and can be trained into any desired shape. It produces large crops of pear-shaped, green figs with a brown tinge, and the flesh ranges from white to amber, sometimes with a red tinge. These figs are great for all purposes and this tree is a reliable cropper. The fruit ripen in early autumn and this tree is self-fertile, although it will produce even more fruit when planted with another fig cultivar. Ficus carica is deciduous and native to the Mediterranean and western Asia. Learn more about Ficus carica.

This fig cultivar produces small to medium-sized fruit with purple-black skin and red flesh. The fruit are rich, very sweet, and are harvested in a small crop during mid-summer, with the main crop ripening from mid to late autumn. The tree is self-fertile, but it will produce a higher yield when planted with another fig cultivar. Ficus carica is deciduous and native to the Mediterranean and western Asia. Learn more about Ficus carica.

This fig cultivar produces long, brown figs with sweet, amber-colored flesh and excellent flavor. It produces a light crop in the summer followed by the main crop in the autumn. The tree is cold-hardy and is self-fertile, although it will produce a higher yield when planted alongside another fig cultivar. Ficus carica is deciduous and native to the Mediterranean and western Asia. Learn more about Ficus carica.

This fig cultivar produces fruit with green-brown skin and sweet amber-pink flesh. It produces a light crop in the summer followed by the main crop in the autumn. The tree is self-fertile, although it will produce a higher yield when planted with another fig cultivar. Ficus carica is deciduous and native to the Mediterranean and western Asia. Learn more about Ficus carica.

This fig cultivar produces fruit with green-yellow skin and pink, sweet, and juicy flesh. It produces a light crop in the summer followed by the main crop in the autumn. The tree is self-fertile, although it will produce a higher yield when planted with another fig cultivar. Ficus carica is deciduous and native to the Mediterranean and western Asia. Learn more about Ficus carica.

This fig cultivar produces dark-purple to red-skinned fruit with a deep-carmine flesh when ripe. The fruit ripens in early to mid-autumn and is an excellent choice for both fresh consumption and drying. The tree is self-fertile, although it will produce a higher yield when planted with another fig cultivar. Ficus carica is deciduous and native to the Mediterranean and western Asia. Learn more about Ficus carica.

This fig cultivar produces unusual green and yellow striped figs with crimson-red flesh. The large, bold, and rich green foliage of the deciduous tree has a tropical appearance over the summer months. The fruit ripens in late autumn and this tree is self-fertile, although it will produce a higher yield when planted with another fig cultivar. Ficus carica is deciduous and native to the Mediterranean and western Asia. Learn more about Ficus carica.

This fig cultivar produces delicious fruit with a sweet flavor and dark-brown to purple-black skin that ripen in early autumn. The tree is self-fertile, although it will produce a higher yield when planted with another fig cultivar. Ficus carica is deciduous and native to the Mediterranean and western Asia.
