This fig cultivar is a compact grower that produces large, long-necked figs with green skin and red inner flesh. It is well-suited for cooler climates and the fruit ripens in late autumn. The tree is self-fertile, although it will produce a higher yield when planted with another fig cultivar. Ficus carica is deciduous and native to the Mediterranean and western Asia. Learn more about Ficus carica.

Fraxinus angustifolia subsp. oxycarpa 'Raywood' has an elegant, pyramidal growth habit when young, which broadens to a rounded canopy with age. It is a popular choice for areas with limited space but a need for height. The new growth is bronze-purple, which turns dark-green over the summer. In the autumn, this tree displays beautiful colors of orange, purple, and red. It is an excellent choice for use as an avenue, driveway, or street tree. Fraxinus angustifolia is deciduous and native to Western Europe north to France and northwest Africa. Learn more about Fraxinus angustifolia. Fraxinus angustifolia subsp. oxycarpa 'Raywood' originated in about 1910 at the Raywood House gardens in Aldgate, Adelaide, Australia and had entered the British nursery trade by 1928 and entered the North American nursery trade in about 1956.

Fraxinus excelsior forms a large, wide-rounded head and is an ideal choice as a shade tree for large areas such as parks and paddocks. It is also well-suited as a stock shelter. The tree features smooth bark and black buds, and in the autumn, the leaves turn yellow. It can tolerate heavy soils and moist conditions, making it a versatile choice for a variety of environments. Fraxinus excelsior is native throughout mainland Europe, Britain, and Ireland. Learn more about Fraxinus excelsior.

Fraxinus excelsior 'Aurea' produces large, bright-green to light-yellow, pinnate leaves throughout the summer months. In the autumn, the leaves deepen to a bright-gold color before dropping, revealing smooth golden bark and black buds. It is an excellent choice for a shade tree. Fraxinus excelsior is native throughout mainland Europe, Britain, and Ireland. Learn more about Fraxinus excelsior.

Fraxinus excelsior 'Aurea Pendula' produces large, pale-green to light-yellow, pinnate leaves throughout the summer months. In the autumn, the leaves deepen to a bright-gold color before dropping, revealing smooth golden bark and black buds. The side branches of this tree weep gracefully towards the ground, giving it an attractive and unique appearance. Fraxinus excelsior is native throughout mainland Europe, Britain, and Ireland. Learn more about Fraxinus excelsior.

Fraxinus excelsior 'Green Glow' features young leaves that are bronze in color, which become lush-green for the rest of the spring and summer. It has a compact and upright growth habit, making it an ideal choice as a street tree or for lining driveways and avenues. In the autumn, the leaves turn yellow, adding a pop of color to the landscape. Fraxinus excelsior is native throughout mainland Europe, Britain, and Ireland. Learn more about Fraxinus excelsior. Fraxinus excelsior 'Green Glow' was developed by Allenton Nurseries in Ashburton, New Zealand (PVR 1214).

Fraxinus excelsior 'Purple Spire' produces glossy, green, pinnate leaves throughout the spring and summer months. In the autumn, the leaves turn a beautiful purple and glowing-orange color, providing a stunning display. It is an excellent choice for lining avenues and driveways or as a street tree, with an upright form. Additionally, this tree can tolerate strong winds, making it a durable option for a variety of environments. Fraxinus excelsior is native throughout mainland Europe, Britain, and Ireland. Learn more about Fraxinus excelsior. Fraxinus excelsior 'Purple Spire' was developed by Frank Goeddert of Frank's Trees in Nelson, New Zealand (PVR 2984).

This fast-growing tree features shiny, green, pinnate leaves and a rounded head, which can be shaped into any desired size and form. In the summer, this tree is covered in large panicles of white flowers, providing a beautiful display. It prefers hot and well-drained conditions but can defoliate in the winter in cold climates. Fraxinus griffithii is an excellent choice as a street tree, providing both shade and beauty to the surrounding area. Fraxinus griffithii is evergreen and native to the Philippines, Indonesia, Vietnam, Myanmar, Taiwan, China, Bangladesh, and India. Learn more about Fraxinus griffithii.

otherCommonNames: Flowering Ash, South European Flowering Ash
description: This lovely tree has a compact growth habit and produces a profusion of fluffy, scented white flowers in the spring. The tree also features handsome, deep-green, pinnate leaves that turn yellow to red-purple in the autumn, providing a stunning display of color. Fraxinus ornus is an excellent choice as a street tree, adding both beauty and fragrance to the surrounding area. Fraxinus ornus is deciduous and native to southern Europe and southwestern Asia. Learn more about Fraxinus ornus.

This hardy, fast-growing tree has an upright growth habit and forms a neat oval head with a straight trunk. It is an excellent choice for a lawn, avenue, street, or park tree. Fraxinus pennsylvanica 'Annesbrook' is seedless. The tree features deep-green, lobed leaves that turn yellow in the autumn, providing a beautiful display of color. Fraxinus pennsylvanica is deciduous and native to eastern and central North America. Learn more about Fraxinus pennsylvanica.

Fraxinus pennsylvanica 'Cimmzam' grows uniformly erect, with glossy-green pinnate leaves that provide an attractive canopy. In the autumn, the leaves turn a fiery orange to red, adding a striking display of color to the surrounding area. The tree is tolerant of drought and high winds, making it a durable option for a variety of environments. It is an excellent choice for lining avenues and driveways or as a street tree, providing both beauty and shade to the surrounding area. Fraxinus pennsylvanica is deciduous and native to eastern and central North America. Learn more about Fraxinus pennsylvanica.

This large and hardy succulent features a trunk that can grow up to 1.5m high, topped with a rosette of blue-grey leaves. In mid-summer, this tree produces a 3m to 4m tall spire of pale-green flowers, which is a unique and striking feature. Unlike other species of Furcraea, this superior form does not die after flowering. Furcraea guatemalensis is an excellent choice for large containers or small gardens, requiring good drainage and full sun to thrive. Furcraea guatemalensis is evergreen and native to Belize, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, southeast and southwest Mexico, and Nicaragua. Learn more about Furcraea guatemalensis.

Fuscospora cliffortioides has an elegant form with graceful spreading branches that grow in tiers, providing a unique and attractive appearance. It will grow in warm climates with adequate moisture and shelter from hot winds. Fuscospora cliffortioides is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Fuscospora cliffortioides.

Fuscospora fusca forms an erect, pyramidal, narrow-growing shape and has small, crinkly leaves that range from brown-green to deep bronze-red. Grows in warm climates with adequate moisture and shelter from hot winds. Fuscospora fusca is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Fuscospora fusca.

Fuscospora solandri features decorative, glossy, dark-green leaves that change color in the winter, adding interest and beauty to the landscape. The tree has black bark and grows slowly in a tiered shape, giving it a unique and attractive appearance. Fuscospora solandri is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Fuscospora solandri.

Fuscospora truncata grows in a similar way to Fuscospora fusca, but is characterized by its glossy, shiny-green leaves. The tree has hard bark that is full of silicone and grows slowly over time, eventually developing into a noble, buttressed tree. Once established, it can tolerate dry conditions and strong winds. Fuscospora truncata is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Fuscospora truncata.

This stunning plant is a lush and glossy grower, featuring dark-green foliage that adds a lush and vibrant look to the landscape. It produces large, highly fragrant white and cream-colored flowers from late spring through to late autumn, providing a beautiful display throughout the growing season. Gardenia 'Professor Pucci' can also be grown as a hedge, adding both beauty and privacy to the surrounding area. It is important to protect this tree from frosts and strong winds to ensure optimal growth and health. Gardenia 'Professor Pucci' is evergreen and not native to New Zealand. Learn more about Gardenia 'Professor Pucci'.

Garrya elliptica is highly adaptable and can tolerate dry and coastal conditions, making it a durable option for a variety of environments. It features small, green, leathery leaves and produces tassels of grey-green to silver-grey flowers from late-winter to early-spring, adding a unique and attractive element to the landscape. Garrya elliptica can also be grown as a hedge, providing both beauty and privacy to the surrounding area. Garrya elliptica is evergreen and native to the coastal ranges of California and southern Oregon in the United States. Learn more about Garrya elliptica.

This hardy tree is highly prized for its beauty and unique appearance. It features distinctive leaves that are shaped like sections of maidenhair fern, providing a one-of-a-kind look to the landscape. In the autumn, the leaves turn a bright gold color over several weeks before falling to create a stunning carpet of gold on the ground. The tree is a beautiful addition to any garden or landscape, adding both visual interest and seasonal beauty. Ginkgo biloba is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Ginkgo biloba.

This selected male clone features a neat and broadly-conical form, making it an excellent choice for many landscapes. The tree is a spectacular sight in the autumn when the leaves turn a bright gold color over several weeks before falling to create a stunning carpet of gold on the ground. This male clone is non-fruiting. Additionally, this tree is tolerant of pollution, making it well-suited for urban environments. Ginkgo biloba is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Ginkgo biloba.

This compact, neat, narrow, and erect-growing tree is an excellent choice for confined spaces where height is required. The tree is a spectacular sight in the autumn when the leaves turn a bright gold color over several weeks before falling to create a stunning carpet of gold on the ground. It is a non-fruiting cultivar. Additionally, this tree is tolerant of pollution, making it an excellent choice as a street tree or for urban landscapes. Ginkgo biloba is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Ginkgo biloba.

This pyramidal tree features jade-green foliage that adds a vibrant and attractive look to the landscape. In the autumn, the foliage turns a soft cream-yellow color, providing a unique and stunning display of color. The tree has a stocky habit, making it well-suited for smaller gardens or landscapes. Overall, it is an excellent choice for adding visual interest and beauty to a variety of outdoor spaces. Ginkgo biloba is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Ginkgo biloba. Ginkgo biloba 'Jade Butterflies' was developed by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand (PVR 1133).

Ginkgo biloba 'Little Weeper' features branches that grow upwards before arching and allowing the outer branches to cascade to the ground, creating a unique and striking appearance. The soft-green leaves of this tree in the spring provide a lush and vibrant look to the landscape, while the golden-yellow leaves in the autumn add a warm and cozy feel to the surroundings. Overall, this tree is an excellent choice for adding beauty and visual interest to a variety of outdoor spaces. Ginkgo biloba is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Ginkgo biloba. Ginkgo biloba 'Little Weeper' originated in Germany.

This miniature cultivar features very fine foliage, creating a delicate and unique appearance. It is important to protect this tree from harsh winds. In the autumn, the leaves of this tree turn a beautiful butter-yellow color, adding a warm and cozy feel to the landscape. Overall, this tree is an excellent choice for adding beauty and visual interest to a small garden or outdoor space. Ginkgo biloba is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Ginkgo biloba. Ginkgo biloba 'Ming Princess' was developed by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand (PVR 1134).

Ginkgo biloba 'Pendula' is an extremely graceful and striking specimen, featuring beautiful broad fans of fern-like foliage that add a unique and attractive element to the landscape. In the autumn, the foliage of this tree turns a stunning golden-yellow color and holds well on this tree until it falls cleanly to the ground. This adds a warm and cozy feel to the surroundings and creates a beautiful display of seasonal color. Overall, this tree is an excellent choice for adding visual interest and beauty to a variety of outdoor spaces. Ginkgo biloba is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Ginkgo biloba. Ginkgo biloba 'Pendula' was first distributed in 1862 by Charles van Geert's nursery in Belgium.

This selected male clone features an upright growth habit and distinctive long leaves that hang from the branches, creating a unique and striking appearance. The tree is a spectacular sight in the autumn, with its yellow leaves providing a stunning display of seasonal color. This male clone is non-fruiting. Additionally, this tree is tolerant of pollution. Overall, this tree is an excellent choice for adding visual interest and beauty to a variety of outdoor spaces. Ginkgo biloba is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Ginkgo biloba. Ginkgo biloba 'Saratoga' originated as a seedling selected in 1975 by the Saratoga Horticultural Research Foundation in California, United States.

Gleditsia triacanthos var. inermis 'Emerald Cascade' features deep-green pinnate leaves that add a lush and vibrant look to the landscape. The strong branches of this tree cascade to the ground, creating a unique and striking appearance. In the autumn, this tree's leaves turn a beautiful golden-yellow color, adding a warm and cozy feel to the surroundings. The tree is an excellent choice for filling in awkward corners, cascading next to water, or as a container plant. It produces small, green-yellow flowers in mid to late-spring, and does not produce thorns. Overall, this tree is an excellent choice for adding beauty and visual interest to a variety of outdoor spaces. Gleditsia triacanthos is deciduous and native to North America. Learn more about Gleditsia triacanthos. Gleditsia triacanthos var. inermis 'Emerald Cascade' was introduced in about 1992 by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand.

Gleditsia triacanthos var. inermis 'Limelight' features leaves that emerge in the spring with a yellow-green color before maturing to a deep-green. In the autumn, the leaves turn a beautiful golden color, adding warmth and coziness to the surroundings. The tree produces small, green-yellow flowers in mid to late-spring, and does not produce thorns. Overall, this tree is an excellent choice for adding beauty and visual interest to a variety of outdoor spaces. Gleditsia triacanthos is deciduous and native to North America. Learn more about Gleditsia triacanthos. Gleditsia triacanthos var. inermis 'Limelight' was developed by Allenton Nurseries in Ashburton, New Zealand (PVR 850).

Gleditsia triacanthos var. inermis 'Ruby Lace' has a round, graceful shape and is well-suited for smaller gardens. Its ferny, pinnate leaves are a purple-red color and turn bronze-red during the summer months. In the fall, the leaves become a deep claret-red before dropping from this tree. Gleditsia triacanthos var. inermis 'Ruby Lace' thrives in hot, dry climates and produces small, green-yellow flowers in the middle to late part of spring. Additionally, it is a thornless variety. Gleditsia triacanthos is deciduous and native to North America. Learn more about Gleditsia triacanthos.

With a straight trunk and compact branches, this tree has an upright form that makes it an ideal choice for limited spaces, as either a shade or specimen tree. Its leaves turn a golden color in the fall and remain that way for an extended period. Gleditsia triacanthos var. inermis 'Skyline' is able to withstand hot and cold temperatures, as well as drought conditions, making it a good option for street planting. It produces small, green-yellow flowers in the middle to late part of spring and is also a thornless variety. Gleditsia triacanthos is deciduous and native to North America. Learn more about Gleditsia triacanthos. Gleditsia triacanthos var. inermis 'Skyline' originated in North America in 1957.

Gleditsia triacanthos var. inermis 'Sunburst' has a neatly rounded shape with a picturesque branching structure that makes it a superb shade tree. Its canopy provides dappled light, which allows grass to grow beneath it. The tree's bright-yellow new leaves contrast beautifully with the fresh, lime-green older leaves. During the fall, its leaves turn a vibrant golden color. It produces small, green-yellow flowers in the middle to late part of spring and is also a thornless variety. Gleditsia triacanthos is deciduous and native to North America. Learn more about Gleditsia triacanthos. Gleditsia triacanthos var. inermis 'Sunburst' originated in the United States in 1947.

Gordonia axillaris is hardy and versatile, able to adapt to different environments. It has thick, glossy, dark-green leaves and produces a profusion of single white flowers with a prominent boss of stamens from autumn to spring. It is able to withstand cold temperatures and windy conditions, making it a resilient option. Gordonia axillaris is evergreen and native to southern China, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Gordonia axillaris.

Gordonia yunnanensis is hardy and versatile, capable of adapting to various conditions. Its red-green new leaves transition to a dark-green color, providing an attractive contrast. The tree produces a profusion of single white flowers with a prominent boss of stamens from autumn to spring, making it an excellent choice for hedging. Gordonia yunnanensis is also able to tolerate shade and withstand cold temperatures and windy conditions, adding to its versatility. Gordonia yunnanensis is evergreen and native to China. Learn more about Gordonia yunnanensis.

When in full flower, this rounded tree is truly breathtaking. It produces huge white flowers with sunshine yellow stamens, which open from fat buds from late autumn to spring. Gordonia yunnanensis 'Moonlight Magic' serves as an important food source for bees during the colder months, making it a valuable addition to any garden. It can be planted in either full sun or semi-shade. Gordonia yunnanensis is evergreen and native to China. Learn more about Gordonia yunnanensis. Gordonia yunnanensis 'Moonlight Magic' was developed by Paradise Plants in New South Wales, Australia (PVR 2141).

Gordonia yunnanensis 'Red Tips' has smaller leaves, and its new growth is red before transitioning into a glossy dark-green color. The tree produces large, single, white flowers with a boss of golden stamens from mid-winter into spring, making it an excellent source of food for bees. Gordonia yunnanensis 'Red Tips' is also a great option for hedging. Gordonia yunnanensis is evergreen and native to China. Learn more about Gordonia yunnanensis.

When young, this tree has an upright, pyramidal shape and large, fern-like, pale-green leaves. As this tree matures, it develops horizontal limbs, creating a broader top. In the spring, mature trees produce amazing clusters of large, yellow-orange flowers, which attract nectar-seeking birds. Grevillea robusta is also able to tolerate coastal winds and dry conditions, making it a resilient option. Grevillea robusta is evergreen and native to eastern Australia. Learn more about Grevillea robusta.

Griselinia littoralis has rich-green, oval, leathery, and glossy leaves on golden stems, and it is a dense grower that can be easily clipped into various forms. It is ideal for use in hedging and screening. Griselinia littoralis is tough and able to withstand extreme temperatures and conditions, with the exception of excessive moisture in the soil. It produces small, green-yellow flowers in late spring to mid-summer. Griselinia littoralis is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Griselinia littoralis.

Griselinia littoralis 'Ardmore Emerald' has dark-green, glossy leaves and is a dense grower that can be easily clipped into various forms. It is ideal for use in hedging and screening, and is able to withstand extreme temperatures and conditions, except for excessive moisture in the soil. It produces small, green-yellow flowers in late spring to mid-summer. Griselinia littoralis is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Griselinia littoralis. Griselinia littoralis 'Ardmore Emerald' was developed by Ardmore Nurseries in Auckland, New Zealand.

Griselinia littoralis 'Broadway Lime' features small, lime-green leaves with an upright growth habit. It is a fantastic hedge plant that can be easily clipped into various shapes, making it an ideal option for low hedging. It is a tough tree and able to withstand extreme temperatures and conditions, except for excessive moisture in the soil. Griselinia littoralis 'Broadway Lime' also produces small, green-yellow flowers in late spring to mid-summer. Griselinia littoralis is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Griselinia littoralis.

Griselinia littoralis 'Broadway Mint' has rich-green, oval, leathery, and glossy leaves with wavy edges, and golden stems. It is a dense grower that can be easily clipped into various shapes, making it a versatile option. The tree is tough and able to withstand extreme temperatures and conditions, except for excessive moisture in the soil. It can tolerate heavy frosts, making it a good option for colder climates. Additionally, this tree produces small, green-yellow flowers in late spring to mid-summer. Griselinia littoralis is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Griselinia littoralis.

Griselinia littoralis 'Canterbury' has small, dark-green, glossy leaves with distinctive red stems. It is a dense grower that can be easily clipped into various shapes, making it an ideal option for hedging and screening. The tree is tough and able to withstand extreme temperatures and conditions, except for excessive moisture in the soil. It can tolerate heavy frosts, making it a good option for colder climates. Additionally, this tree produces small, green-yellow flowers in late spring to mid-summer. Griselinia littoralis is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Griselinia littoralis.

Griselinia littoralis 'Gecko Green' is a compact grower with dense, glossy, emerald-green foliage. It is an excellent option for low-hedging due to its tidy and compact growth habit. The tree is tolerant to wind and coastal conditions, but it requires a well-drained site in full sun to semi-shade. It produces small, green-yellow flowers in late spring to mid-summer. Griselinia littoralis is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Griselinia littoralis.

Griselinia littoralis 'Variegata' has rich-green, wavy leaves that are blotched and irregularly margined with pale-gold. It is a dense grower that can be easily clipped into various shapes, making it an ideal option for hedging and screening. The tree is able to tolerate most soils, except for those that are poorly drained. It produces small, green-yellow flowers in late spring to mid-summer. Griselinia littoralis is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Griselinia littoralis.

Griselinia littoralis 'Whenuapai' has large, glossy, dark-green leaves that form a tight, narrow column, making it an excellent choice for architectural plantings. The foliage has a distinctive pointed leaf tip, which gives it a neat and tidy appearance. It is ideally suited for hedging, topiary work, and coastal plantings. Griselinia littoralis 'Whenuapai' prefers fertile, well-drained soils in full sun to part shade and is a hardy variety. Additionally, it produces small, green-yellow flowers in late spring to mid-summer. Griselinia littoralis is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Griselinia littoralis. Griselinia littoralis 'Whenuapai' was developed by Kiwi Flora in Auckland, New Zealand (PVR 2520).

Griselinia lucida is bushy and has stout, erect stems that are clothed in large, highly-polished, fresh-green leaves. It can grow in either sun or shade, and adds a luxuriant tropical feel to the garden. It is also an excellent option for containers. Griselinia lucida is able to tolerate coastal conditions and is hardy against light frosts. Griselinia lucida is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Griselinia lucida.

Hedycarya arborea is an attractive erect-growing specimen with dark-green leaves. It produces small, white flowers in late spring to late summer, which are followed by large, orange fruit in early autumn to mid-winter. It is important to plant more than one tree, with both male and female specimens, to ensure the production of fruit. Hedycarya arborea requires good soil with adequate moisture and shelter from frosts in order to thrive. Hedycarya arborea is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Hedycarya arborea.

otherCommonNames: Hibiscus, Syrian Ketmia, Shrub Althea, Rose Mallow
description: Hibiscus syriacus 'Snowdrift' is a multi-stemmed grower that produces large, single, white flowers which cover the bush from mid-summer to early-autumn. It is able to grow equally well in cold and hot climates. To encourage new stems to flower the following summer, it is recommended to prune this tree by half after the flowering period. Hibiscus syriacus is deciduous and native to Korea and south-central and southeast China. Learn more about Hibiscus syriacus.

Hoheria angustifolia grows into a slender shape with graceful, semi-weeping branches. It has narrow, elongated leaves with heavily-serrated edges, adding to its unique appearance. During the summer, this tree produces great masses of star-shaped white flowers, creating a stunning display. Hoheria angustifolia is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Hoheria angustifolia.

Hoheria populnea is very graceful, with slender branches that add to its delicate appearance. Its fresh-green leaves are heavily-serrated, giving them a distinctive texture. During the summer, this tree produces great masses of star-shaped white flowers, creating a beautiful display. It is an excellent option for rapid screening. Hoheria populnea is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Hoheria populnea.

Hoheria populnea 'Alba Variegata' is very graceful, with slender branches that add to its delicate appearance. Its dark-green leaves are heavily and irregularly margined with cream-white, creating an eye-catching contrast. Hoheria populnea 'Alba Variegata' makes for a magnificent shade tree and can brighten up dark areas in a garden. During the summer, it produces great masses of star-shaped white flowers, adding to its beauty. Hoheria populnea is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Hoheria populnea. Hoheria populnea 'Alba Variegata' was discovered in New Zealand in the 1920s on a Hoheria populnea 'Variegata'. Hoheria populnea 'Alba Variegata' was first listed by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand in an undated catalogue from about 1930.

Hoheria populnea 'Purple Wave' is an erect-growing variety with dark-green leaves that are purple underneath, giving them a unique appearance. During the summer, this tree produces great masses of star-shaped white flowers, adding to its aesthetic appeal. Hoheria populnea 'Purple Wave' is a quick and hardy grower, making it an excellent option for use as a screen or as a specimen tree. Hoheria populnea is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Hoheria populnea.

Hoheria populnea 'Variegata' is very graceful, with slender branches that add to its delicate appearance. Its larger leaves are dark-green with irregular yellow blotches and margins, creating a unique and eye-catching contrast. Hoheria populnea 'Variegata' makes for a magnificent shade tree and can brighten up dark areas in a garden. During the summer, it produces great masses of star-shaped white flowers, adding to its beauty. Hoheria populnea is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Hoheria populnea. Hoheria populnea 'Variegata' originated in New Zealand and was listed in 1926 in the catalogue of Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand.

Hoheria sexstylosa has a graceful form with slender branches, forming an erect columnar shape. Its pointed green leaves are heavily-serrated, adding to its unique appearance. During the summer, this tree produces great masses of star-shaped white flowers, creating a beautiful display. Hoheria sexstylosa is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Hoheria sexstylosa.

Hoheria sexstylosa 'Purple Lace' is very graceful, with slender branches forming an erect columnar shape. Its pointed green leaves are purple underneath, giving them a unique appearance. In late summer to autumn, this tree produces large clusters of star-shaped, fragrant white flowers that almost obscure the branches. Hoheria sexstylosa 'Purple Lace' is an excellent option for rapid screening, and it adds beauty and fragrance to any garden. Hoheria sexstylosa is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Hoheria sexstylosa.

Hymenosporum flavum has an erect and graceful open form and is a very fast grower. Its glossy, dark-green leaves add to its attractive appearance. During late spring through summer, this tree produces clusters of honey-scented, yellow, tubular flowers. Hymenosporum flavum is tolerant of dry and windy conditions, making it a hardy option for a variety of environments. It is also well-suited for smaller gardens. Hymenosporum flavum is evergreen and native to Australia and New Guinea. Learn more about Hymenosporum flavum.

Idesia polycarpa 'Female' has a tiered horizontal branch structure and a broad crown. It produces red berries in autumn, but requires the male Idesia polycarpa 'Male' for pollination. Both male and female forms produce small, yellow-green flowers during the summer. In the autumn, this tree's leaves turn yellow, adding to its aesthetic appeal. Idesia polycarpa is deciduous and native to China, Japan, Korea, and Taiwan. Learn more about Idesia polycarpa.

Idesia polycarpa 'Male' has a tiered horizontal branch structure and a broad crown, and is characterized by its handsome heart-shaped leaves. Both male and female forms produce small, yellow-green flowers during the summer. In the autumn, this tree's leaves turn yellow, adding to its aesthetic appeal. It serves as a pollinator for Idesia polycarpa 'Female'. Idesia polycarpa is deciduous and native to China, Japan, Korea, and Taiwan. Learn more about Idesia polycarpa.

Ilex x altaclerensis 'Hendersonii' has an upright, pyramidal form and features spineless leaves. During the winter, it produces clusters of red berries, which add to its aesthetic appeal. It is an excellent option for screening and hedges, and can be trimmed into any shape. Ilex x altaclerensis is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Ilex aquifolium and Ilex perado. Learn more about Ilex x altaclerensis. Ilex x altaclerensis 'Hendersonii' was developed by Thomas Hodgins in Dunganstown, Ireland in the early 19th century.

Ilex crenata 'Sky Pencil' has a narrow, columnar-growing habit with small, dark-green, spineless leaves. It is an excellent option for use as a screen, as it doesn't require side pruning. Additionally, this tree is a great option for use in containers or as a focal point in a contemporary garden due to its unique appearance. Ilex crenata is evergreen and native to eastern China, Japan, Korea, Taiwan, and Sakhalin Island. Learn more about Ilex crenata. Ilex crenata 'Sky Pencil' was discovered by Norihiro Shibamichi on Mount Daisen, Japan. Ilex crenata 'Sky Pencil' found its way to the private collection of Masato Yokoi in Kawaguchi, Japan. Masato then donated propogation material to Sylvester March and Frederick Darke during a United States National Arboretum collecting trip in 1985. Ilex crenata 'Sky Pencil' was then introduced into commerce by the United States National Arboretum in 1992.

Ilex 'Largo' features dark-green foliage and has an upright, bushy growth habit. It is an excellent option for use in topiary and hedging, as it is easy to trim into various shapes. Ilex 'Largo' prefers to be planted in full sun for optimal growth. Ilex 'Largo' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and was developed in New Zealand.

Ilex x meserveae 'Blue Angel' is a female cultivar and features dark, blue-green, soft, spiny leaves with purple-black stems. It is a slow, dense, upright grower and produces a profusion of small, white blossoms during the summer. To attain scarlet red berries in autumn, it is recommended to plant this tree in combination with the male pollinator Ilex x meserveae 'Blue Prince'. Ilex x meserveae 'Blue Angel' can tolerate semi-shade and cold conditions. Ilex x meserveae is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Ilex aquifolium and Ilex rugosa. Ilex x meserveae was first crossed by Kathleen Meserve in St. James, New York in the 1950s. Ilex x meserveae 'Blue Angel' was developed by Kathleen Meserve in St. James, New York in the 1950s (USPP03662).

Ilex x meserveae 'Blue Prince' is a male cultivar and features dark, blue-green, spiny leaves with purple-black stems. It is a slow, dense, bushy grower and produces a profusion of small, white flowers during the summer. It is recommended to plant this tree as a companion pollinator to the female Ilex x meserveae 'Blue Angel'. Ilex x meserveae 'Blue Prince' is an excellent option for use in hedging and can tolerate semi-shade and cold conditions. Ilex x meserveae is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Ilex aquifolium and Ilex rugosa. Ilex x meserveae was first crossed by Kathleen Meserve in St. James, New York in the 1950s. Ilex x meserveae 'Blue Prince' was developed by Kathleen Meserve in St. James, New York in the 1950s (USPP3517).

Jacaranda mimosifolia is best suited for warm, sunny climates with no frosts. It has soft, ferny leaves that cover the spreading branches radiating from the single trunk. During the spring and early summer, this tree produces large, lavender-blue, trumpet-like flowers that are borne in racemes. Jacaranda mimosifolia is an excellent option for use as a shade tree. Jacaranda mimosifolia is semi-evergreen and native to northwestern Argentina and southern Bolivia. Learn more about Jacaranda mimosifolia.

Juglans nigra is a fast-growing option with a tall, straight trunk and a wide, spreading head. It is characterized by its dark-brown to black bark and the walnuts that ripen during the autumn months. These walnuts are edible and have a desirable taste, but can be more difficult to extract compared to those produced by Juglans regia. Additionally, this tree is self-fertile. The wood of this tree is highly-valued for commercial purposes, such as furniture. Juglans nigra is deciduous and native to North America. Learn more about Juglans nigra.

Juglans regia is a slow-growing option with a wide-spreading, rounded head. It is an excellent choice for planting in paddocks. Juglans regia produces easy-to-crack walnuts during the autumn months, usually around fifteen years from planting. During the late spring to early summer, this tree produces yellow-green catkins which serve as a source of pollen for bees. While this tree is self-fertile, it can produce better crops when planted with a walnut cultivar like Juglans regia 'Meyric', Juglans regia 'Shannon', or Juglans regia 'Wilson's Wonder'. Juglans regia is deciduous and native to the region stretching from the Balkans eastward to the Himalayas and southwest China. Learn more about Juglans regia.

Juglans regia 'Meyric' produces large walnuts and prefers free-draining soil. It typically starts producing walnuts at around five years of age. The brown nuts are held in a green husk. While this tree is self-fertile, it can produce better crops when planted with another walnut cultivar like Juglans regia 'Shannon' or Juglans regia 'Wilson's Wonder'. Juglans regia is deciduous and native to the region stretching from the Balkans eastward to the Himalayas and southwest China. Learn more about Juglans regia. Juglans regia 'Meyric' was discovered by Chris Ryan in Hawkes Bay, New Zealand and then propagated by Vernon Harrison.

This is a top-quality walnut tree that produces large crops of well-flavored nuts. The nuts are easy to crack and are held in a green husk. The tree prefers free-draining soils and typically starts producing walnuts at around five years of age. While it is self-fertile, it can produce better crops when planted with another walnut cultivar like Juglans regia 'Meyric' or Juglans regia 'Wilson's Wonder'. Juglans regia is deciduous and native to the region stretching from the Balkans eastward to the Himalayas and southwest China. Learn more about Juglans regia. Juglans regia 'Shannon' was propagated by Vernon Harrison in New Zealand.

Juglans regia 'Wilson's Wonder' is vigorous and starts bearing at a young age, producing large thin-shelled nuts with a sweet flavor. It thrives in free-draining soil and begins to bear walnuts at around three years old. The nuts are brown and encased in a green husk. While self-fertile, planting with another walnut cultivar like Juglans regia 'Meyric' or Juglans regia 'Shannon' can lead to better crops. Juglans regia is deciduous and native to the region stretching from the Balkans eastward to the Himalayas and southwest China. Learn more about Juglans regia. Juglans regia 'Wilson's Wonder' was imported into New Zealand by Vernon Harrison and others.

Juniperus chinensis 'Kaizuka' has long, gracefully-curving branches growing out at all angles that are covered in dense clusters of bright-green leaves, making it an architectural focal point. It is also able to tolerate strong winds. Juniperus chinensis is evergreen and native to China, Myanmar, Japan, Korea, Mongolia, Taiwan, and the Russian Far East. Learn more about Juniperus chinensis. Juniperus chinensis 'Kaizuka' originated around 1920 at Yokohama Nursery in Yokohama, Japan.

This is a narrow-growing, columnar conifer with blue-grey foliage that is suitable for use as a screen or windbreak. Once established, it is drought-tolerant and rarely requires pruning. However, it does require full sun to thrive. Juniperus scopulorum is evergreen and native to western North America, from southwest Canada to the Great Plains of the United States. Learn more about Juniperus scopulorum. Juniperus scopulorum 'Skyrocket' was discovered and named in 1949 by Schuel Nursery in South Bend, Indiana, United States.

Knightia excelsa has a narrow, columnar form similar to a poplar and is ideal for planting in restricted areas where height is desired. It has large, long, heavily-serrated, leathery leaves and produces red flowers in early summer that attract nectar-seeking birds. The tree can tolerate poor soils, light frosts, and strong winds, making it an excellent choice as a street tree. Knightia excelsa is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Knightia excelsa.

Koelreuteria paniculata has an open, spreading form and is adorned with pinnate leaves. The leaves emerge as soft-pink in spring, mature to green, and turn yellow in autumn. In early summer, this tree produces panicles of golden-yellow flowers which are followed by dangling, rose-red, papery capsules. It thrives in regions with hot summers and cold winters and is an excellent choice as a street tree. Koelreuteria paniculata is deciduous and native to China and Korea. Learn more about Koelreuteria paniculata.

Kunzea robusta features small, narrow, dark-green, and aromatic leaves that are soft to the touch. In early summer, it produces sprays of glistening white flowers. Kunzea robusta is very hardy, withstanding frosts, drought, and poor soils with ease. It's an excellent choice for use as a screen or to provide shelter for more tender plants. Additionally, it is attractive to bees, making it a great choice for supporting pollinator populations. Kunzea robusta is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Kunzea robusta.

This weeping tree produces beautiful, golden-yellow blossoms in late spring. It grows best in full sun and requires soil that won't dry out over the summer. The tree can also be trained to grow over an archway for added interest and beauty. Laburnum alpinum is deciduous and native to Albania, Austria, Czechoslovakia, France, Greece, Italy, Switzerland, and Yugoslavia. Learn more about Laburnum alpinum.

Laburnum x watereri 'Vossii' has a compact, rounded head and produces fragrant racemes of yellow flowers that hang from the branches in late spring. Its branches are pliable enough to be trained over high arches, adding architectural interest to any landscape. The tree does not produce seeds, and it's an excellent choice as a street tree. Laburnum x watereri is a hybrid between Laburnum anagyroides and Laburnum alpinum. Laburnum x watereri is deciduous and native to Switzerland. Learn more about Laburnum x watereri. Laburnum x watereri 'Vossii' was raised in the Netherlands in the late 19th century.

Lagerstroemia fauriei 'Townhouse' has a compact, rounded head and smooth, mottled bark. It produces lime-green leaves in the spring, which mature to green in the summer before turning brilliant red, orange, and yellow in the autumn. In the summer, this tree produces large, cone-shaped panicles of pure-white flowers. It can handle moderate winds and has beautiful red-brown bark. Lagerstroemia fauriei is deciduous and native to Japan. Learn more about Lagerstroemia fauriei. Lagerstroemia fauriei 'Townhouse' arose as a chance seedling at the JC Raulston Arboretum in Raleigh, North Carolina, United States and was selected in the 1980s.

Lagerstroemia indica 'Bergerac' has a compact, rounded head and smooth, mottled bark. Its lime-green leaves in the spring transition to green in the summer before turning brilliant shades of red, orange, and yellow in the autumn. In the summer, this tree produces large conical panicles of crimped, deep-pink to red flowers. Lagerstroemia indica is deciduous and native to India, Bangladesh, Cambodia, China, the Himalayas, Myanmar, Nepal, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Lagerstroemia indica. Lagerstroemia indica 'Bergerac' was selected by Desmartis & Cie. in Bergerac, France and was introduced into commerce in 1978.

Lagerstroemia indica 'Crimson Red' features beautiful, deep red-purple to black foliage that emerges in early spring. During the summer, masses of vivid crimson-red flowers cover this tree. In the autumn, the foliage turns orange and red, adding to its seasonal appeal. Lagerstroemia indica is deciduous and native to India, Bangladesh, Cambodia, China, the Himalayas, Myanmar, Nepal, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Lagerstroemia indica. Lagerstroemia indica 'Crimson Red' was developed by Cecil Pounder at the United States Department of Agriculture. Lagerstroemia indica 'Crimson Red' was then distributed by J. Berry Nursery in Grand Saline, Texas, United States.

Lagerstroemia indica 'De'Puard' has a compact, rounded head and smooth, mottled bark. It produces lime-green leaves in the spring that mature to green in the summer before turning brilliant shades of red, orange, and yellow in the autumn. Lagerstroemia indica is deciduous and native to India, Bangladesh, Cambodia, China, the Himalayas, Myanmar, Nepal, Taiwan, and Vietnam. Learn more about Lagerstroemia indica.

Lagunaria patersonia is evergreen and native to Norfolk Island and also the states of New South Wales and Queensland in Australia. Learn more about Lagunaria patersonia.

Laurus nobilis forms a compact, pyramidal shape and has leathery, dark-green leaves that are used for flavoring food. It is very amenable to pruning and shaping into any form, making it a great choice for those who want to maintain its size and shape. It can also be used to make a dense, aromatic hedge. This quick-growing tree has red young stems and is covered in small, bronze-purple leaves that smother its arching branches. It can be pruned to form a dense, colourful shelter or screen. The tree produces a profusion of single, white flowers in the summer. It is very hardy and can tolerate drought conditions. Leptospermum nitidum is evergreen and native to Tasmania, Australia. Leptospermum scoparium makes an excellent screen or shelter and is fast-growing and very hardy. It can tolerate hot dry soils and cold temperatures. Leptospermum scoparium 'Electric Red' produces a vibrant display of red flowers in the spring, completely covering the bush and creating a stunning burst of color in the garden. Leptospermum scoparium 'Princess Anne' produces beautiful, double, white flowers with a dark-maroon center in the spring, making it a stunning addition to any garden or landscape. Leptospermum scoparium 'Princess Anne' is hardy and prefers full sun with free-draining soil, and is also frost and drought tolerant once established, making it a great choice for a wide range of growing conditions. Libocedrus plumosa is a handsome, symmetrical, pyramidal tree that features bright-green, scale-like leaves. Liquidambar acalycina has large, three-lobed leaves, with rich, purple-bronze new spring leaves that add a striking pop of color to the garden. In the fall, this tree's leaves turn a gorgeous apricot-orange and yellow, and persist on this tree well into the winter, providing seasonal interest. Liquidambar acalycina has a smooth bark and a dense, conical growth habit. Liquidambar acalycina is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Liquidambar acalycina.

Liquidambar styraciflua forms a stately, pyramidal tree with well-spaced branches and rugged, corky bark. Its shining, five to seven-lobed, maple-shaped leaves provide a handsome look to this tree. In the autumn, this tree puts on a riot of red, orange, yellow, and purple colors over a long period, making it a great choice for adding seasonal interest to the garden. The tree's coloration is known to be consistent across different climates. However, it's important to note that this tree develops a taproot in dry soils that helps reinforce it against wind, but in wetter soil, it only grows superficial roots and cannot tolerate much wind. Liquidambar styraciflua is native from central and eastern United States to Central America. Learn more about Liquidambar styraciflua.

Liquidambar styraciflua 'Burgundy' is a selected clone with a narrower, pyramidal form when young, which broadens with age. It features larger maple-shaped leaves that emerge earlier than other cultivars. In the autumn, this tree's leaves turn a rich, red-burgundy color, which persist well into winter, providing seasonal interest. Liquidambar styraciflua 'Burgundy' is known to color well in all climates and is an excellent choice for use as a street tree. It is important to note that in dry soil, this tree produces a taproot that helps reinforce it against wind, but in wetter soil, it only grows superficial roots and cannot tolerate much wind. Liquidambar styraciflua is native from central and eastern United States to Central America. Learn more about Liquidambar styraciflua. Liquidambar styraciflua 'Burgundy' was selected in 1963 by the Saratoga Horticultural Foundation in California, United States.

Liquidambar styraciflua 'Festeri' has smooth bark and puts on a brilliant autumn display of red, purple, yellow, and orange colors that can last well into winter in warmer areas, making it an excellent choice for adding seasonal interest to the garden. However, it's important to note that in dry soil, this tree produces a taproot that helps reinforce it against wind, but in wetter soil, it only grows superficial roots and cannot tolerate much wind. Liquidambar styraciflua is native from central and eastern United States to Central America. Learn more about Liquidambar styraciflua. Liquidambar styraciflua 'Festeri' was discovered by Mr Fester, a gardener at Kenmore Hospital in Goulburn, New South Wales, Australia and was named in his honour by the Hazelwood Brothers nursery in New South Wales, Australia in 1947.

Liquidambar styraciflua 'Golden Treasure' has large green leaves that are broadly-margined with gold, providing a striking look to this tree. During the autumn season, the leaves take on glowing red and burgundy hues, adding to its beauty. The round-headed growth habit makes it an ideal choice for smaller gardens. It is known to color well in all climates. However, it's important to note that in dry soil, this tree produces a taproot that helps reinforce it against wind, but in wetter soil, it only grows superficial roots and cannot tolerate much wind. Liquidambar styraciflua is native from central and eastern United States to Central America. Learn more about Liquidambar styraciflua. Liquidambar styraciflua 'Golden Treasure' was introduced by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand before 1974.

Liquidambar styraciflua 'Gumball' has a dense, rounded ball-shaped growth habit and features maple-shaped leaves that turn brilliant shades of purple, orange, yellow, and red in the autumn. These leaves often persist well into the winter, providing an extended period of seasonal interest. Liquidambar styraciflua 'Gumball' is an excellent choice as a street tree or for formal planting, and it does not produce seed capsules. However, it's important to note that in dry soil, this tree produces a taproot that helps reinforce it against wind, but in wetter soil, it only grows superficial roots and cannot tolerate much wind. Liquidambar styraciflua 'Lane Roberts' has a neat, pyramidal growth habit with smooth bark and distinctive, rich crimson-red to purple autumn leaves. Liquidambar styraciflua 'Lane Roberts' reliably produces brilliant fall colors every year, regardless of the climatic conditions. It's an excellent choice as a street tree. However, it's important to note that in dry soil, this tree produces a taproot that helps reinforce it against wind, but in wetter soil, it only grows superficial roots and cannot tolerate much wind. Harold Hillier noticed Liquidambar styraciflua 'Lane Roberts' when he visited the garden and first listed it in The Hillier Manual of Trees and Shrubs in 1971.

Liquidambar styraciflua 'Lees Red' is known for coloring early and holding its colorful crimson-red leaves until early winter. In dry soil, it produces a taproot that helps reinforce it against wind, but in wetter soil, it only grows superficial roots and cannot tolerate much wind. Liquidambar styraciflua is native from central and eastern United States to Central America. Learn more about Liquidambar styraciflua. Liquidambar styraciflua 'Lees Red' was selected from a tree growing on Lees Road in Feilding, New Zealand.

This is a dwarf selection with a narrow, upright growth habit. The leaves turn a brilliant red and orange in autumn, and it tolerates moist and clay soil conditions. In dry soil, it produces a taproot that helps reinforce it against wind, but in wetter soil, it only grows superficial roots and cannot tolerate much wind. Liquidambar styraciflua is native from central and eastern United States to Central America. Learn more about Liquidambar styraciflua. Liquidambar styraciflua 'Little Richard' is very popular in New Zealand, but is believed to be of Australian origin.

Instead of pointed lobes like other cultivars, this tree has round leaf lobes. It also has smooth bark. During the summer, it has shining green leaves and grows narrowly and pyramidally. In the fall, this tree's leaves turn a glowing burgundy-red color. It does not produce seeds and is an excellent choice for planting along streets. When grown in dry soil, this tree develops a taproot that helps reinforce it against wind, while in wetter soil, it only grows superficial roots and is less tolerant of strong winds. Liquidambar styraciflua is native from central and eastern United States to Central America. Learn more about Liquidambar styraciflua. Liquidambar styraciflua 'Rotundiloba' was discovered by R. E. Wicker near Pinehurst, North Carolina, United States and was first described by Alfred Rehder in 1931.

The tree has an upright, pyramidal shape, and its outer branches droop gracefully. Its leaves are similar in shape to those of a maple tree, with fine cuts and deep lobes. In the autumn, this tree's leaves are a striking mix of purple, red, orange, and yellow. When grown in dry soil, this tree develops a taproot that helps to reinforce it against wind. However, when grown in wetter soil, this tree only produces superficial roots and is not able to tolerate strong winds. Liquidambar styraciflua is native from central and eastern United States to Central America. Learn more about Liquidambar styraciflua. During summer, this robust tree produces yellow, orange-banded, tulip-shaped flowers. It is a rare species that has blue-green leaves of remarkable size, which transform into a butter-yellow hue during autumn. The tree has a broad, columnar shape and purple-tinted emerging leaves. It is an outstanding choice for planting in parks and paddocks. Liriodendron chinense is deciduous and native to China and Vietnam. Learn more about Liriodendron chinense.

Liriodendron tulipifera is a magnificent, tall, pyramidal specimen with a broad, spreading crown. Its beautiful bright-green leaves transform into a glorious butter-yellow hue during autumn. In summer, it produces fragrant yellow, orange-banded, tulip-shaped flowers. It is an excellent choice as a large lawn and paddock tree. Liriodendron tulipifera is deciduous and native to eastern North America. Learn more about Liriodendron tulipifera.

In spring, this tree displays beautiful butter-yellow leaves which fade to yellow-green during summer, and its autumn foliage is a deep gold. It has a neat, broadly-conical growth habit, but it grows slower than Liriodendron tulipifera. However, its yellow foliage is more prone to burning in very hot weather. In summer, this tree produces fragrant yellow, orange-banded, tulip-shaped flowers. Liriodendron tulipifera is deciduous and native to eastern North America. Liriodendron tulipifera 'Aureomarginatum' has strikingly variegated large green leaves that are heavily bordered with a rich golden-yellow. In summer, this tree produces fragrant yellow, orange-banded, tulip-shaped flowers. Liriodendron tulipifera is deciduous and native to eastern North America. Learn more about Liriodendron tulipifera. Liriodendron tulipifera 'Aureomarginatum' was first noted by Louis van Houtte in Belgium in 1869.

With a narrow, upright, and columnar form, this tree is an excellent choice for confined spaces, avenues, screens, or focal points in formal gardens. Its beautiful green leaves in summer turn a glorious butter-yellow during autumn. It is also an excellent street tree. Liriodendron tulipifera 'Snowbird' has a pyramid shape with up-swept branches. Its large green leaves are strikingly variegated and heavily-bordered with cream-white. The tree displays golden-yellow autumn leaves. In summer, this tree produces fragrant yellow, orange-banded, tulip-shaped flowers. This is a fast-growing tree that can tolerate drought once established. Its wood is strong and durable, and is commonly used in shipbuilding, making floors and bridges, and for general building timber. The tree features salmon-colored bark that flakes off during summer, revealing orange-brown tones on the trunk. It produces clusters of small white flowers in both spring and summer. Lophostemon confertus is evergreen and native to Australia. Learn more about Lophostemon confertus.

Lophozonia menziesii has an erect, pyramidal, and narrow-growing form. It features small, deep-green leaves, and its young spring growth appears pale-green against the silver-white trunk. The tree prefers cooler climates but can grow in warm climates with adequate moisture and shelter from hot winds. Lophozonia menziesii is evergreen and native to New Zealand. Learn more about Lophozonia menziesii.

Loropetalum chinense var. rubrum 'Fire Dance' has deep red-purple leaves that may fade to green during the summer. It produces beautiful, bright-pink flowers from early spring, making it a stunning choice for low-hedging. Once established, this tree is drought-tolerant. Loropetalum chinense is evergreen and native to China. Learn more about Loropetalum chinense.

Macadamia 'GT205' has been specifically bred to withstand cooler and wetter growing conditions, and it begins producing at an early age. The nuts are enclosed in a green shell which turns brown and drops in mid-spring to early summer, although they can be hand-picked earlier. Macadamia 'GT205' produces heavy yields of nuts with a high oil content, making it an excellent choice for roasting. Cross-pollination with another macadamia cultivar, such as Macadamia 'GT207' or Macadamia integrifolia x tetraphylla 'Beaumont', is necessary. Macadamia 'GT205' also boasts pink flowers that bloom in both spring and summer. Macadamia 'GT205' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and was bred by Ian Gordon in Titirangi, Auckland, New Zealand.

Macadamia 'GT207' is an excellent choice for a home garden, as it drops ripe nuts, making harvesting easier. The early-season nuts have a high oil content and are ready to be harvested in mid-autumn to early-winter. Cross-pollination with another macadamia cultivar, such as Macadamia 'GT205' or Macadamia integrifolia x tetraphylla 'Beaumont', is necessary. Macadamia 'GT207' also produces pink flowers in both spring and summer. Macadamia 'GT207' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and was bred by Ian Gordon in Titirangi, Auckland, New Zealand.

Macadamia integrifolia x tetraphylla 'Beaumont' produces new leaves that are red-maroon in color, and bright-pink flowers that bloom from spring to summer. It begins bearing macadamia nuts at a young age and continues to improve with age. The brown nuts, enclosed in a green husk, are typically borne from summer to autumn. Unlike some other cultivars, this one does not drop its own crop, so the nuts must be picked by hand. Although it is partially self-fertile, planting it with another macadamia cultivar such as Macadamia 'GT205' or Macadamia 'GT207' can result in better crops. Macadamia integrifolia x tetraphylla 'Beaumont' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and an Australian selection that was trialled at the John H. Beaumont Agricultural Research Center in Hawaii, United States in the 1930s.

Magnolia acuminata 'Koban Dori' produces soft-yellow, cup-shaped blooms with six tepals that are typically 5cm to 7.5cm wide. The flowers appear in the spring as the leaves begin to emerge, and this tree is an excellent choice for adding color to a mixed garden or brightening up a dull corner. It is an upright, pyramidal grower, adding to its aesthetic appeal. Magnolia acuminata is deciduous and native to Ontario, Canada and the central and eastern United States. Learn more about Magnolia acuminata. Magnolia acuminata 'Koban Dori' was introduced in Japan before 1989.

Michelia 'Allure' has a tight and compact form, making it a great choice for screening or creating a topiary. It also features attractive foliage, and in the winter, it produces striking flower-buds that add to its visual appeal. Additionally, it produces delightful blush-pink spring flowers. Michelia 'Allure' can be grown in both sun or light shade and is also suitable for growing in pots. Michelia 'Allure' is correctly known as Magnolia 'Allure', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia 'Allure' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and was developed in New Zealand.

Magnolia 'Amethyst Flame' produces bright purple-pink blooms in the spring and is a free-flowering tree. It begins to bloom at a young age and continues to produce an abundance of flowers. Magnolia 'Amethyst Flame' has an upright, sturdy, shrub-like growth habit and tends to clump from the base, adding to its aesthetic appeal. Magnolia 'Amethyst Flame' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia liliiflora and Magnolia 'Vulcan'. Magnolia 'Amethyst Flame' was raised by Vance Hooper at Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand and was named in about 1995.

Magnolia 'Arabian Nights' is a strong, upright, and rounded grower that tends to get larger with age. In the early spring, it produces a profusion of large, bowl-shaped blooms with a rich purple-red color, adding to its visual appeal. Magnolia 'Arabian Nights' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia 'Sayonara' and Magnolia 'Vulcan'. Magnolia 'Arabian Nights' was raised by Stuart Robertson in about 2000 at the Auckland Botanic Gardens in Auckland, New Zealand and was named in about 2007.

Magnolia 'Athene' is an erect, vase-shaped tree that becomes more rounded as it matures. It starts flowering from an early age and should produce its first blooms within a year of planting. The large, fragrant flowers are cup and saucer-shaped with thick and rounded tepals. The flowers are ivory-white, but they are also flushed with violet-pink at the base, adding to their visual appeal. Magnolia 'Athene' typically blooms in the mid-spring. Magnolia 'Athene' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia x soulangeana 'Lennei Alba' and Magnolia 'Mark Jury'. Magnolia 'Athene' was bred by Felix Jury in New Zealand in the early 1960s and introduced in 1988.

Magnolia 'Atlas' produces large, cup-shaped flowers that are lilac-pink in color with cream-white interiors. The flowers can reach up to 35cm in diameter, with tepals that are up to 15cm wide. It typically blooms in mid-spring and starts producing flowers from an early age. Magnolia 'Atlas' has an erect and open-headed tree form, but it only produces flowers at the branch tips, adding to its unique visual appeal. Magnolia 'Atlas' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia x soulangeana 'Lennei Alba' and Magnolia 'Mark Jury'. Magnolia 'Atlas' was bred by Felix Jury in New Zealand in the 1960s and introduced in 1989.

Has masses of fragrant, white flowers with a blush of rose-pink at the base in spring. Rounded habit. Magnolia 'Billowing Cloud' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia x soulangeana 'Amabilis' and Magnolia cylindrica. Magnolia 'Billowing Cloud' was raised by Vance Hooper at Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand.

Cup-shaped, thick-textured blooms of glowing dark-purple. Flowers are usually 15cm wide and are wind-resistant. Flowers from an early age. An upright, compact tree ideal for the smaller garden. Mid-spring flowering. Magnolia 'Black Tulip' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia 'Vulcan' and Magnolia 'Iolanthe'. Magnolia 'Black Tulip' was raised by Mark Jury in Tikorangi, Taranaki, New Zealand and introduced in 1998 (PVR 1498).

Large, cup and saucer-shaped, rich-pink flowers with pale-pink interiors. Flowers from the first year in tremendous abandon. A neat, spreading tree, suited to the smaller garden. Mid-spring flowering, sometimes having a second summer flowering. Magnolia 'Brixton Belle' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia campbellii 'Sir Harold Hillier' and the hybrid formed between Magnolia x soulangeana 'Sweet Simplicity' and Magnolia 'Black Tulip'. Magnolia 'Brixton Belle' was raised by Vance Hooper in Brixton, Taranaki, New Zealand and released into commerce by Magnolia Grove in Waitara, Taranaki, New Zealand about 2010.

Flowers are green and purple-pink outside with yellow-white interiors veined with pink. An upright grower. Late-spring flowering. Excellent street tree. Magnolia x brooklynensis is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia acuminata and Magnolia liliiflora. Magnolia x brooklynensis was first crossed in the 1950s by Evamaria Sperber at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden's Kitchawan Research Station in New York City, New York, United States. Magnolia x brooklynensis 'Woodsman' is a hybrid between Magnolia acuminata 'Klassen' and Magnolia liliiflora 'O'Neill'. Magnolia x brooklynensis 'Woodsman' was raised by Joe McDaniel in Illinois, United States and first flowered in 1972.

Produces masses of beautiful yellow flowers in spring as the leaves emerge. Flowers have six tepals that are usually 7.5cm to 10cm long and have a slight green tinge when the flower first opens. An upright, pyramidal grower. Magnolia x brooklynensis is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia acuminata and Magnolia liliiflora. Magnolia x brooklynensis was first crossed in the 1950s by Evamaria Sperber at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden's Kitchawan Research Station in New York City, New York, United States. Magnolia x brooklynensis 'Yellow Bird' is a hybrid between Magnolia x brooklynensis 'Evamaria' and Magnolia acuminata var. subcordata. Magnolia x brooklynensis 'Yellow Bird' was raised by Doris Stone in 1967 at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden's Kitchawan Research Station in New York City, New York, United States.

Glowing, wine-red, large, slightly-fragrant flowers. Very floriferous cultivar which flowers from an early age and for a prolonged period. Flowers are up to 25cm wide. Narrow, erect grower. Great where space is limited. Mid-spring flowering. Excellent street tree. Magnolia 'Burgundy Star' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia liliiflora 'Nigra' and Magnolia 'Vulcan'. Magnolia 'Burgundy Star' was raised in 1993 by Mark Jury in Tikorangi, Taranaki, New Zealand and was introduced in 2006 (PVR 30707).

Very free-flowering with a mass of cream-yellow, star-shaped flowers that sit atop the branches like butterflies in spring. Flowers emerge before the leaves and have 10 to 14 tepals and red stamens. Forms a rounded tree and flowers from an early age. Magnolia 'Butterflies' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia acuminata 'Fertile Myrtle' and Magnolia denudata 'Sawada's Cream'. Magnolia 'Butterflies' was raised by Phil Savage before 1989 in Michigan, United States.

Tulip to cup-shaped blooms in spring. The flower tepals are red-purple on the outside and white flushed with red-purple on the interior. Wind-resistant blooms are produced in abundance from the first year. The high rate of flower production restricts the height of this tree, keeping it small with a compact habit. Magnolia 'Cameo' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia x soulangeana 'Sweet Simplicity' and Magnolia 'Black Tulip'. Magnolia 'Cameo' was selected in 2000 by Vance Hooper in Waitara, Taranaki, New Zealand and released in 2013 by Magnolia Grove in Waitara, Taranaki, New Zealand (USPP27222).

A glorious show of huge, white, cup and saucer-shaped flowers from late-winter to early-spring. Flowers can be up to 30cm across. Magnolia campbellii 'Alba' takes around five years to commence flowering but is well worth waiting for. Large, upright-growing tree with wide-spreading branches. Magnolia campbellii is deciduous and native to China, Myanmar, Nepal, Tibet, and the Himalayas. Learn more about Magnolia campbellii.

A glorious show of huge, purple-pink, cup and saucer-shaped flowers with white flushed pink interiors from late-winter to early-spring. Flowers are 23cm wide with 12 tepals. Magnolia campbellii 'Charles Raffill' takes around five years to commence flowering but is well worth waiting for. Large, upright-growing tree with wide-spreading branches. Magnolia campbellii is deciduous and native to China, Myanmar, Nepal, Tibet, and the Himalayas. Learn more about Magnolia campbellii. Magnolia campbellii 'Charles Raffill' was selected in the 1960s from seedlings sent by Charles Raffill of Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew in Richmond, United Kingdom (that he worked on in the 1940s) to The Valley Gardens, Windsor Great Park in The Crown Estate Windsor Great Park, United Kingdom.

A magnificent magnolia which tantalizes with large, woolly buds that open to reveal large, cupped, deep-magenta blooms aging to deep-purple. Flowers from late-winter to early-spring. May take a few years to flower but worth the wait. Flowers can be up to 23cm wide and leaves are usually 25cm long by 15cm wide. Plant in a sheltered spot for best results. Upright grower, good for narrow sites. Magnolia campbellii is deciduous and native to China, Myanmar, Nepal, Tibet, and the Himalayas. Learn more about Magnolia campbellii. Magnolia campbellii 'Lanarth' arose from a seedling collected by George Forrest in China in 1924 that was planted at a garden in Lanarth, Cornwall, England.

Large cup and saucer-shaped flowers of red-pink to purple in spring. Flowers are usually 20cm to 30cm wide. Upright to spreading grower. Magnolia 'Charisma' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia 'J. C. Williams' and Magnolia 'Vulcan'. Magnolia 'Charisma' was selected before 2018 by Ian Baldick in Drury, New Zealand.

Flowers from an early age with a profusion of flowers. Goblet-shaped blooms are red-purple inside and out. Flowers are up to 20cm wide. Early-spring flowering with a second summer flowering in warm summers. Excellent street tree. Upright, conical grower well-suited to areas where space is limited. Magnolia 'Cleopatra' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia x soulangeana 'Sweet Simplicity' and Magnolia 'Black Tulip'. Magnolia 'Cleopatra' was selected in 2003 by Vance Hooper in Waitara, Taranaki, New Zealand (PVR 30845).

Large, cup and saucer-shaped flowers of pure-white with a hint of pink at the base. Flowers from an early age. A delightful spreading tree suited to smaller gardens. Early-spring flowering. Magnolia 'David Clulow' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia x soulangeana 'Lennei Alba' and Magnolia x veitchii 'Peter Veitch'. Magnolia 'David Clulow' was selected before 1998 by John Giordano from the hybrids produced by Todd Gresham from 1955 to 1969 at Todd's home in Santa Cruz, California, United States.

Goblet-shaped, pure-white flowers with broad, fleshy petals glisten on the bare branches from late-winter to early-spring. Broad pyramidal form with wide-spreading branches. Flowers from an early age. Magnolia denudata is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Magnolia denudata.

The same beautiful flowers as Magnolia denudata, but flowers later in mid to late-spring. Useful to grow in areas that get late frosts. Forms an upright, pyramidal tree. Flowers from an early age. Excellent street tree. Magnolia denudata is deciduous and native to China. Learn more about Magnolia denudata. Magnolia denudata 'Gere' was selected before 1987 by Joe McDaniel from a tree in a cemetery in Urbana, Illinois, United States and was given the name on the nearest tombstone.

Has rich, glowing, velvet-red flowers from late-winter to early-spring. Sets flowers on all tips, so will tend to be slower-growing. Magnolia 'Deryk' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a seedling of Magnolia 'Genie'. Magnolia 'Deryk' was raised by Magnolia Grove in Waitara, Taranaki, New Zealand and named in honour of Deryk Lawrence who raised various magnolia hybrids at the garden he developed with his wife, Nancy, in Otamarakau, New Zealand.

Strong-growing, neatly-formed, pyramidal tree. From early-spring to early-summer, produces highly-perfumed, large, cream-white, magnolia-like blooms from showy, brown, furry buds. Glossy, rich-green leaves. Drops leaves when flowering but quickly refoliates. Michelia doltsopa is correctly known as Magnolia doltsopa, but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia doltsopa is evergreen and native to Bhutan, Myanmar, China, India, and Nepal. Learn more about Magnolia doltsopa.

A selection of Magnolia doltsopa which flowers from its first years. Large, cream-white flowers from early-spring to early-summer. Flowers are up to 20cm wide with about 30 tepals. Michelia doltsopa 'Silver Cloud' is correctly known as Magnolia doltsopa 'Silver Cloud', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia doltsopa is evergreen and native to Bhutan, Myanmar, China, India, and Nepal. Learn more about Magnolia doltsopa. Magnolia doltsopa 'Silver Cloud' was selected in the 1950s or 1960s by Duncan & Davies Nurseries in New Plymouth, New Zealand from a seedling sent to New Zealand by Hillier Nurseries in the United Kingdom.

A dense, bushy grower with shining, pale-green leaves. From early-spring, bears a profusion of long, russet buds which open to fragrant, lilac-pink flowers with cream-white interiors. Ideal for hedging, pruning into any shape, or growing as a specimen tree. Michelia 'Fairy Blush' is correctly known as Magnolia 'Fairy Blush', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia 'Fairy Blush' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and was bred by Mark Jury in Tikorangi, Taranaki, New Zealand and introduced in 2008 (PVR 3094).

Has shining, pale-green leaves and a strong, horizontal branching structure which makes it ideal for training, especially pleaching. From early-spring, bears long, russet buds which open to star-shaped, fragrant, cream flowers. Will grow as a specimen tree. Michelia 'Fairy Cream' is correctly known as Magnolia 'Fairy Cream', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia 'Fairy Cream' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and was bred by Mark Jury in Tikorangi, Taranaki, New Zealand and introduced in 2013 (PVR 31113).

Has shining, pale-green leaves and a strong, horizontal branching structure which makes it ideal for training, especially pleaching. From early-spring, bears long, russet buds which open to star-shaped, fragrant flowers of pure-white. Michelia 'Fairy White' is correctly known as Magnolia 'Fairy White', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia 'Fairy White' is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and was bred by Mark Jury in Tikorangi, Taranaki, New Zealand and introduced in 2013 (PVR 31112).

Large, cup-shaped, heavily-textured, fragrant flowers of red aging to rose-pink. Flowers are up to 35cm wide. Flowers from an early age. Upright grower with spreading branches and large leaves. Flowers mid-spring. Magnolia 'Felix' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia 'Atlas' and Magnolia 'Vulcan'. Magnolia 'Felix' was raised in 1986 by Mark Jury in Tikorangi, Taranaki, New Zealand and introduced in 2000 (PVR 1875).

Dense, multi-stemmed grower with glossy, pale-green leaves right down to the ground. Small yellow and pink flowers hide among the leaves and impart a fruity fragrance from late-spring through summer. Ideal for hedging, pruning into any shape, or growing as a specimen tree. Michelia figo is correctly known as Magnolia figo, but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia figo is evergreen and native to China and probably originated in cultivation. Learn more about Magnolia figo.

Forms a wide-spreading, pyramidal tree with glossy, deep-green leaves. Velvet buds open to slightly-fragrant, cream-white, rounded flowers with pink edges in spring. Michelia x foggii 'Bubbles' is correctly known as Magnolia x foggii 'Bubbles', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia x foggii is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia figo and Magnolia doltsopa. Magnolia x foggii was first crossed in 1972 by John Fogg at the Morris Arboretum in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, United States. Learn more about Magnolia x foggii. Magnolia x foggii 'Bubbles' was developed before 2000 by Oswald Blumhardt in Whangārei, New Zealand.

Forms a pyramidal tree with shining, pale-green leaves. Velvet buds open to deliciously-fragrant, cream-white, rounded flowers with purple edges in spring. Leaves drop as the flowers emerge but quickly refoliate once flowering has finished. Michelia x foggii 'Mixed Up Miss' is correctly known as Magnolia x foggii 'Mixed Up Miss', but the incorrect name has been retained for consistency with the New Zealand market. Magnolia x foggii is evergreen, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia figo and Magnolia doltsopa. Magnolia x foggii was first crossed in 1972 by John Fogg at the Morris Arboretum in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, United States. Learn more about Magnolia x foggii. Magnolia x foggii 'Mixed Up Miss' was developed before 1996 by Oswald Blumhardt in Whangārei, New Zealand.

In spring, produces lightly-scented, goblet-shaped flowers that are deep-pink at the base fading to pink-white near the top. Flowers have 9 to 11 tepals. An upright growing tree. Magnolia 'Forrest's Pink' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and usually listed as a Magnolia denudata cultivar. However, unpublished data has shown that it is almost certainly a hybrid. Its precise parentage remains unknown. Magnolia 'Forrest's Pink' was raised as a seedling (possibly from one of George Forrest's seed collections) in the 1920s at Caerhays Estate in Cornwall, England.

Flowers in late-spring are initially tulip-shaped and are red-purple at the base, fading to pink near the top and inside. Ideal in areas that get late frosts. Fragrant flowers with a sweet smell are up to 25cm wide and have 11 to 12 tepals. Upright, pyramidal grower that spreads with age. Flowers from an early age. Excellent street tree. Magnolia 'Galaxy' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia liliiflora 'Nigra' and Magnolia sprengeri var. diva 'Diva'. Magnolia 'Galaxy' was developed in 1963 by William Kosar at the United States National Arboretum in Washington, D.C., United States and was released into commerce in 1980.

Goblet-shaped flowers are dark purple-red. Flowers for about ten weeks through spring with a second summer flowering. Flowers have up to 12 tepals. Produces healthy leaves and is proven to be frost hardy. Ideal where space is limited. Magnolia 'Genie' is deciduous, not native to New Zealand, and a hybrid between Magnolia 'Sweet Valentine' and the hybrid formed between Magnolia x soulangeana 'Sweet Simplicity' and Magnolia liliiflora 'Nigra'. Magnolia 'Genie' was selected by Vance Hooper in 1998 in Waitara, Taranaki, New Zealand (PVR 2853).

Bears a profusion of fragrant, large, star-shaped flowers of soft cream-yellow. Flowers have up to 14 tepals. Mid-spring flowering. Bronze-red spring leaves become green through summer. An upright grower with spreading branches.
